text: Stockbridge June 10th1811 I have retired from our little family Circle at an earlier hour than usual to devote a little time to the delightful occupation of writing my dear Robert. I am afraid you will number this among the instances in which the giver is more blessed than the receiver. Be that as it will, I am determined not to let another mail pass, without an acknowledgement of my gratitude for your last most kind letter. Heaven grant you the appropriate reward of such tenderness, I cannot bestow it -- Brother is the most comprehensive word in my vocabulary. The definition of it with the variousreadings, occupy at least a dozen folio pages in the volume of my heart. I cannot transcribe it, for the heart only can receive the inscription of such characters as express it -- -- Our dear good little Sister has settled down to her common humdrum occupations with as much ease and contentment as if she had not had a peep at the great City & her gay Brother. “She seeketh wool & flax, & worketh diligently with her hands” and illustrates every day this sentimental truth that “Une ame saine peut donner du goût à des occupations communes”. By the way my dear Bob I begin to doubt whether mon ame is quite as saine as it should be. At any rate I am sure that solitude & meditation are not friendly to the virtues of my character. I sit sometimes for hours together in a corner of my room indulging the sickly fancies of a discontented spirit, & forgetful of those best bless blessings of Heaven that surround me. I am indeed ashamed of these ideal miseries & blush that the delightful realities of my condition should yield for a moment to their dominion _____ Such is the imperfection of all human happiness. “Man was made to mourn” & mourn we must, even when the brightest beams of youth & joy illumine our path. In the mid career of all my moralizing the Judge has called me to the stairs to tell me, that he had forgotten to write to Mr Watson ‘till just as he was going to bed, very late; & that he will write both to him and to you next week. Papa and Mrs S leave us in a few days for a jaunt to Conadarque. Papa wished very much to have taken Charles in her place, but her ill health is a pretext from which there is no appeal -- Why do you say nothing of your sweet favorite Gertrude? Surely my dear Bob you cannot mean to extinguish “the sacred lowe o’ weel plac’d love” nor can I beleive the empire of such loveliness can be transient -- -- I think our Modern independence answers to the tilts & tournaments of former times, & that He who speaks the prettiest oration (to use our own Stockbridge dialect) is entitled to a Laurel from the fair hand of the Lady, to whom his heart has sworn allegiance. I should like to see Miss GirtrudeKimbal the heroine of such a ceremony; & thenext thing you’d see my dearest Robert’s brow encircled by a wreath not only “freshened and nourished by the breath of renown” by but by the bright glance & vivifying smiles of the “Lady of the ascendant” -- I received a letter from Lucy last week for which I beg you to assure her she shall shortly receive my thanks in black & white -- We all hope Frances will leave you tomorrow, but as we got no letter by the mail today we are at a loss what arrangements to make -- If she has not left you I wish you would request her to buy me black twilled cambric for a frock do not forget this & two squares more of such cravat cambric as Eliza bought. My best love to my dear Brother. It is almost superfluous for me, to express my joy at the final adjustment of his business with Whiting -- Eliza says the first letter she writes will be to you --The family are all well -- Good night dear Bob. I cannot tell you how much I wish you was here to exchange our customary good night salutation -- C M Sedgwick PS. Mr Watson has eleven barrels of Cider remaining here. His direction was to have ten left ‘till he gave farther orders. I wish he would let us know whether he wishes them sent.

Stockbridge Dec 7th 1803 I hardly know My Dear Sister ILL whose letter to answer yours or Mr Watsons I feel greatly my inability to give you any pleasure by my letters or Mr Watson. no I will not say so for I know you are ever anxious to hear of the health and welfare of your friends. I wish you were all here to participate in our happiness for although Theodore and the dear Boys have left us yet we have many sources of amusement from Papas presence happiness and instruction is always to be desired Mama endeavours to instil into us every thing that is laudable Aunt Dwight carefulness and Uncle Bob though he performs his usual round everyday is a very agreeable inmate. I will not pass over Theodore the younger lest his honour should take offence We are astonished at his wisdom daily. At present I go to school study Geography Grammar and read history write and spell all of which the master is very capable of teaching He is a Gentleman from Hebron. In the evening Papa reads to us in something that is equally instructive and entertaining I am reading Robertsons Charles the 5th at home at school Humes History of England I have almost finished the former the latter I have but just begun. The more I read Robertson the more I am pleased with him I do not know hardly which to like best his History of Scotlandnd or Charles the 3 5th I think Charles resembles Elizabeth very much Francis appears to be an open generous Prince while Charles is quite the reverse he is constanly deceiving Francis who judging of him by his own heart generally beleives him Francis entertained him in his own dominions with generosity tho he didnot love him Charles pretended to repose perfect confidence in him but yet was always fearful of him knowing what perfidious arts he should use if Francis was in his situation, but my Dear sister why should I be tiring you in this way when you understand it much more perfectly than I do I do not know how to express my gratitude and thanks to Mr Watson for his kind letter to me how are you blessed my Sister in having such a Husband a husband who is ever attentive tothr the interest and welfare of his beloved wife and darling child who indeed are worthy of his love your. Your little Boy (but it is almost impossible for me to speak of him) grows in every thing that is interesting and charming I suppose the next time we hear from him he will walk. Your domestic felicity is almost without bounds may it continue so -- -- Mama is much better than she was when last I wrote you she begs me to give her most affectionate love to you your Husband and a kiss to the sweet boy you didnot tell her how you liked your ‘girls she feels quite impatient to hear I believe has been writing to you Aunt Dwight has been very sick but is better she wishes to be remembered affectionately to you all Charles sends his love to you he is very much obliged to you for your letter I am very much pleased with my Hat and Shawl I think they both do justice to your taste. pray give my best love to my Dear Dear Brother and kiss the sweet boy for me I shall answer Mr Watsons letter next week. Adeiu My Beloved Sister beleive me your very affectionate Sister Catharine Maria Sedgwick do excuse the manner in which this letter is wri tten I have written it at school and had no other paper to copy it off, my arm is constantly joggled and the schollars whispering the mail closes this evening and it is almost dark I have just now come home and told uncle Bob that I had written to you that we hardly ever see him at Home his answer was I will be damned if I ant in the house all the time. I will acknowledge he has reformed in a measure. Catharine Sedgwick

1807-12-25 Catharine Maria Sedgwick FSW Catharine Maria Sedgwick to Frances Sedgwick Watson Patricia Kalayjian, Lucinda Damon-Bach, Deborah Gussman CMSOL Patricia Kalayjian 2018-08-28 Sedgwick Family Relations Sedgwick Family Residences Childbirth/Pregnancy Childcare Friendship Authorship I beleive my dear Sister that Harry has told you as much about the youthful stranger as there is to tell; after exhausting the only subject by expatiating on which I should hope to a communicate much pleasure, he has resigned to me a worn out pen a dry inkstand, and finally a forlorn hope -- Little Ebb sits by my side, and spares no pains in dictating every thing, that in his opinion will amuse you -- Notwithstanding the fertility of his inventions, does not at all accellerate my progress in my letter and I fear his most “polished efforts” committed to paper, would lose half their beauty where they of necessity lose the varied and soft tones of his voice, and the concomitant lustre and sweetness, that emanates from beautiful eyes -- -- I should be solitary indeed without this little charmer, who is very often my only companion, and I may with truth add, my only solace for many long hours. Secluded, I alone in this east room, this very place which has so often seemed the favorite resort of “mirth and youthful jollity” is now during a great part of the day almost deserted, Eben and myself being the sole occupants -- I frequently, perhaps too frequently review the scenes through which we have passed in this home, endeared by a thousand ties of love and gratitude -- Here we have mutually shared the approving smiles and caresses of the fondest parents, the tenderest affection of the best Brothers; and here, my beloved Frances, my dearest Sister, have we together shared every opinion, every thought, every thing that elevated us with joy, or depressed us with sorrow But now separated, and afflicted, all all seems fled -- -- -- Do not my Sister misunderstand me, I should be ungrateful beyond measure if although robbed of some blessings, I did not feel the pleasure from the possessions of others -- -- Your letters since they are all that I can now have of you, are inestimable to me -- You my dear Frances are the only person from whom I have received a single line, since my return -- I have sometimes hoped that as Susan knew how much a letter from her would gladden my heart, she would make an effort to gratify me -- Her friends in New York are very numerous, and probably occupy all her attentions, as all my solicitations through the medium of your letters have as yet been ineffectual -- I should once more repeat them, but I fear vainly -- -- Papa has not yet returned from N Hampton -- He was very well when we heard from him. -- -- He found a great deal more business, and more troublesome than he expected, so that he will probably be detained nearly all next week -- Eliza has so far been remarkably well -- It is exactly one week this evening since she was confined. She has not yet seen your letter, but has most affectionately enquired after you -- We often together talk of you, and I always my dear Frances think Charles is very well and begs to be affectionately remembered to you and Mr Watson -- -- Mumbet is with Eliza at present, and is very well -- She has renewed this winter the exercise of her kind care towards Eben -- I beg my dear Frances that you will remember me affectionately to my Brother -- -- Kiss the Children for me -- -- -- I have absolutely promised Eliza to go and see her this afternoon, and I shall therefore spare you with a shorter letter than usual -- -- my love to Matilda -- -- Believe me my dear Frances most affly Yours CMS -- -- -- Eben has kindly shaded my letter, with his blots --

Albany Feb'y 10 1818. Here am I at last dear Robert -- -- I returned with Susan on Friday last -- She passed a few days with us, and we went together to visit our good old Uncle John. The Genius of the Cornwal-hills arrayed himself in all his fury to greet the delicate nerves of his City visitor -- -- Snows and winds did greatly prevail against us -- But we made our way safely thro’ the drifts and returned with a renewed impression of our excellent Uncle’s patriarchal wisdom and goodness, -- It is delightful to perform a duty in relation to such a Man, to throw it upon such a soil -- -- I want very much to have our dear Jane see Uncle, before the effacing hand of time, has impaired the strong features of his character Jane is so perfectly inartificial herself, that I am sure she would admire such a noble chef-d’oeuvres of nature’s canny-hand as Uncle John -- -- -- I have never written since I received your excellent letter, written soon after your return -- I was grateful and gratified at your expressions in relation to our sanctified home -- May it never fail my dearest Brother to pour all its joys into your bosom! I left home with regret -- I always do -- but I think every time I feel a severer pang -- We are so few, and so dependent upon each-other that I always feel the reproach of selfishness when I seek happiness elsewhere -- Besides our domestic establishment needs all my vigilance to keep it in operation. Our Kitchen is made up of such discordant materials that I sometimes think we must throw them all into the “Barathrum” before we have any peace -- I hope you are all comfortably established in Greenwich Castle by this time -- I think of you all by day, and dream of you all by night -- I should not write you such a little bit of a letter, but my eyes are troublesome and I find writing tires them more than any thing else -- My best love to H and J. -- Susan Mrs S & the Children send a great deal of love -- Maria says if there is room enough in my letter, she wishes I would send a kiss to Uncle Robert -- Farewell my dear Brother God bless you Yours as everCMS My dear Mrs Brush -- Is there any use in my apologizing for giving you trouble? if there is I will ‘down upon my knees, and say what you please”. If I once begin I am sure I shall never end, that is, if the effect is at all in proportion to the cause -- You know I have aeconomical fits, and I hoped to have got along decently till I went to NYork in the Spring, without getting a new dress, but I find that my old ones, which looked very smart in the Country look very shabby here -- -- There is no decent Canton crape to be obtained here -- -- I had rather pay more for one of the best quality -- -- Will you get me one black and Susan wishes you to send ‘Rob Roy’ the moment it comes from the press and charge it to her -- -- I have opened my letter to say that I do not wish you to give the subjoined PS to Mrs B -- I have determined to musquash along as well as I can without the crape --

New York Nov'r 22'nd1808 We received your letter my dear Papa from Salem, yesterday Morning -- it is incomprehensible to us, that you should not have received any of Frances’s letters -- She has written three times, since you have been in Boston -- You say nothing of my poor representative, from which I presume you have received it. I confess its insignificance rendered it unworthy of an acknowledgement, but you know my dear Papa, there is a kind of parental pride in Authorship, which is perhaps too easily wounded and if I were ingenuously to tell you all, I should be compelled to confess that your addressing your letters exclusively to my elder Sister, has excited a little of that jealousy; which is a portion of my inheritance from the paternal estate I presume you will have heard long before this letter reaches Boston, of Theodore’s and Susan’s arrival in this City -- Susan is already almost recovered, by the most simple remedy in the world, the presence of her grand restorative, who may well boast with in relation to her, to be as universal a cure, as the most wonder working patent Medicine -- They are to be joined in holy wedlock on monday evening next, at Brockholst Livingston’s, in as private a manner, as propriety will admit of -- Her Aunts, and one or two very dear friends, Mr Watson, our dear Charles provided he arrives in season, Frances and myself are to compose the nuptial train -- Theodore has obtained a triumph similar to yours, and won a promise from poor Susan, that she will sacrifice her liberty of conscience, and be married in a most anti-dogmified,, plebian style, by a Presbyterian Clergyman, -- They will leave New York on the Wedn’y following, in Captain Bunker’s packet and will probably arrive at our dear home a fortnight before you -- -- You seem to have had some uneasiness excited by the secrecy of a late letter, written to me. You will I am sure be gratified to hear, that it was a motive of generosity towards me, that induced the kind writer of it, the refuse you the perusal of it -- I empower you my dear Papa to request her to show you the last letter I wrote her on the subject, if it is still in being that, together with a few words of explanation, or confession, (whichever you please to term it) will acquaint you with an affair about which, I should never have had any reserve towards you, had I not feared that it would have diminished that confidence, which you have so bountifully reposed in me -- -- -- -- -- Last Spring while I was in Boston, Miss Russell told she thought MrsJ unfriendly to her, she had it from several sources, mentioning Mrs Derby, , and I beleive James Savage. I was indignant at MrsJ’s continued & unparalleled abuse of a friend, who I thought so underserving of it -- I confirmed her suspicions, and moreover specified some of the articles of defamation, though it was but a “sand on the sea shore” compared to the whole number -- I know not what motives you will ascribe to this conduct -- Perhaps you will think it was the common, tale-bearing, tattling propensity of a silly girl -- Permit me to say my dear Father I was not motivated by a feeling so dishonorable to me -- On a calm review of it, I have censured myself for it because I was indebted to Mrs -- for much kindness and because the communication, could subserve no good end but never shall I think the impulse that led me to it execrable -- Do my dear Papa, relieve me, by your opinion on the subject, and let it be as lenient as possible -- -- The family all unite with me in the kindest remembrance to you, and yours. -- With the most ardent prayers for your health and happiness beleive me Your affy Catharine M Sedgwick

Stockbridge May 27th1811 I have in vain tried my dear Robert the efficacy of vinegar (which you know in modern times is as good as the waters of Helicon) to remove a violent headache in order that you might cheerfully pay a shilling for my letter. My pain and my dullness are invincible & my epistolaryhorizon, as Mr Jefferson would say is in as utter darkness as the aforesaid Philosopher could have desired for his entire security in a certain cave. -- -- PapaMrs S.Charles, & Pamela left here this morning on a visit of condolence to Uncle John I am left a alone to tell it the sole prop & pillar of the house. All the Chevaliers of the Town have with a truly chivalric spirit volunteered their services. Among the rest young Edwin bowed & I unlike my jilting prototype of old have selected him as my true Knight & valiant Defender. Voltaire says of one of his Heroes “Il était aussi sage qu’on peut l‘être; car il cherchait à vivre avec des sages.” If the same meaning would hold good as to virtue I might erect myself into a model of excellence from this instance of preference of Edwin’s society -- Mrs Sedgwick had a very ill turn yesterday in consequence of indigestion. Papa was so much alarmed that he says he thought she would not have survived it. I was at Eliza’s at the time & did not see her. She is certainly seriously out of health, but I beleive it is almost entirely the consequence of her mode of living. Whether the powers of digestion would be improved or restored by a change of regimen I cannot tell. I think she has much more influence over Papa than she ever had before he feels certain that she will never recover. Her wants and suffering inspire that tenderness which she has no qualities to excite -- Happy indeed is it for her my dear Robert that our excellent Father’s compassionate heart extends its sympathy & kindness to the wants of every creature within the sphere of his affections _____ I need not tell you how severe a sufferer I am by the departure of Harry -- too was very sad at the idea of going. He is too domestic in his affections and habits to conform with any satisfaction to the formalities of fashionable intercourse; he would rather have one flash of the “lightning of eyes” than all the heartless civilities of a life of etiquette & would prefer a half an hour’s quiet snapping of his penknife in our chimney corner to the dazzling splendor of an Otis Ball -- We shall I trust my dear Robert if a gracious Providence spares our lives all meet in September. I confess I am sometimes heartsick when I think that we shall not meet ‘till then. In the meantime my dearest Brother do not neglect the only means of alleviating the pain of separation _____ Papa will be dreadfully disappointed if Frances does not come with Eliza I cannot imagine that she will not come; therefore I do not feel as anxious as he does, tho’ I beleive I have not less pleasure in the expectation Thank Mr Watson most particularly for his kind notice of me in Harry’s letter. I wish you would tell the little Madam that her family are quite as well without her as with her. Miss Pamela was taken to Co on the ground of her being more an Invalid than Watson -- The dignity of the female part of the family has devolved upon Eliza the heart of all little things, & she supports it as if she had “stirred up her womanish thoughts with a manly spirit” -- -- Eben & Catharine are charmingly the latter often talks of Uncle Robert and avows her preference of him to all her Uncles -- -- -- -- Adieu my beloved Brother -- While I live there will be one heart most fondly & devotedly attached to you Once more adieu Ever Yours C M Sedgwick

text: Stockbridge 19th June 1812 If I hadnot got my name up with you my dear Robert, I wouldnot venture to write tonight, for in the first place it is very late, & in the second, I have no paper in my room but these vile folio sheets, to which I have long had a rooted antipathy -- You must allow my dear Bob that if I have not an ‘eye that never winks,’ I have a pen that never tires, and is ever ready to devote all its honors (which indeed are light as the feather that adorns it) to your service -- -- -- -- -- Our dear Father returned from Cornwal last evening, the weather has been extremely unfavorable for his jaunt -- Owing to that perhaps, he has had a recurrence of his asthmatic affection -- He has just gone to bed after a severe turn of it, which I think was aggravated by a walk to Aunt Dwight’s after the dew had fallen. Alas my dear Robert, how feeble is the thread by which our happiness is suspended -- I don’t know whether it was since you left home, that Harry informed us, that Danforth is of opinion that this asthma is a affection of the gout -- Jones is of the same opinion, & that nothing but a genuine fit in the extremities will be a radical relief -- I beleive Papa is now so much alarmed, that he would gladly consent to the omission of the mischievous steam -- Should Papa be better next week, he intends taking Mrs S. & myself to Albany to pass a day or two with our dear Sue previous to her departure for W. Chester -- I shall send you by the steamboat next week 4 shirts which are now all but in a state of readiness -- -- -- -- I wish you would tell Frances that I have delivered her message faithfully to Aunt Dwight -- She says it would be impossible for her, in the present state of her family to accommodate Frances, but that she will take Catharine, and do her duty to her in the performance of every act of kindness to her -- This condition however is annexed, that her washing shall be put out, as Aunt has no servant but a little girl -- I think Frances had better send both Eben & Catharine at once -- When I first told Papa that Frances thought of sending the Children to Aunt D -- he asked with some surprise “why she didnot send them here”. Afterwards however he seemed to think the other arrangement much the best, and expressed what we all feel great delight in the expectation of having his favorite Eben again with him -- There cannot be a more favorable situation than Aunt D’s for C. considering Mary’s school -- -- -- By the way, speaking of M’s school, reminds me that I have borrowed the book of our little Genius The Bradley to copy some poetic effusions which I am sure you will think with me have rare merit -- The first is the close of a little pretty prose essay on Friendship Who would lose the secret pleasure/Felt when soul with soul unites?/Other blessings have their measure --/Friendship without bound delights -- Is not the sentiment of this my dear Robert as honorable to her heart as the poetry is to her head Evening The Sun withdraws his golden light Far hid behind yon western hill, The moon arises Queen of night -- And nature’s all serene and still. Now the twilight's gently closing Exchanged for deeper shades of night, 'Tis the hour of pensive musing -- Formed for sad but soft delight. Now Evening’s sweetest warbler Begins his note so soft and long -- Methinks I could forever wander, And listen to the charming song. You know I have often told you that the scene of the setting sun was more beautiful in our little vally than any where else -- This I said in humble prose, you now have the proof in the sensibility it excited in this little girl -- She wrote the last while sitting at Mrs Nash’s west window, and threw it away as unworthy a second perusal -- Mary accidentally found it -- -- Let me have your opinion of it -- -- -- As yet I have received no return for my “polished effort” from C W -- -- My best love to all the family -- -- Little Bob is perfectly well -- -- -- -- Poor Eliza has been quite ill with a violent cold -- She is now recovering -- Sue is much better -- all the rest are well -- Write dearest Bob whenever you have leisure inclination out of the question -- Joh is at Lebanon, apparently almost gone with a hectic!! I have not yet thanked you for your letter by Mr H -- This jumble is intended, to be a bribe for another Mrs S is wonderfully better in all respects I intended this letter should have been to F instead of you, but I felt so stupid when I began it that I determined to saddle it upon you -- Thank Mr W for his very kind letter I intend answering it next week -- Love and kisses for the Children If Doctor Mason should do me the honor to enquire after me present him my most affectionate respects.

New York Febr'y 20th1812 Your letters dear Charley are like Angel's visits in more than this point of resemblance that “they are few and far between” -- I am afraid if an Angel was to vouchsafe me the honor of a visit, she would not come with words so sweetly soothing, as those dictated by a Brother’s partial kindness. I should hear a very different story when the words came to be weighed in the ballances of truth. Indeed my dear Charles all the sermons I hear in a month, & all the writers on human depravity with Hopkins at their head, and all the misanthropic sayings of all the old Bachelors & cynics that have ever lived cannot counteract the ‘sweet morsels,’ I cannot call it, but the mass of flattery you have so elegantly served up in your letter. It has been said by some great or wise man, & by a thousand that are neither wise nor great, that habit is second nature, now by the Aid of this wonderful operation, I had just begun to be reconciled to the sight of my own features in the mirror of truth, (and a picture more delightfully horrible no trafficker in human woes could desire) when your letter arrived, and turned me as impulsively from the hateful reality to the sweet illusion it presented, as I would shut my eyes upon a spectacle of misery to dreams of happiness. The next letter that you write by way of unraveling this web of mischief, I desire may be filled with extracts from Hopkins’ diary, Edwards’ meditations, and Uncle West’s sermons -- Well, my dear Charles in spite of my absence, which I will confess, you deplored with truly fraternal moanings, you have had by all accounts a charming Season of revelry. As for Uncle Bob, I desire you will tell him that considering how long we have been affianced, & the many tender professions I have received from him, I do think all this ‘mirth and jollity’ unbecoming in my absence, and that I can never forgive him unless he expiates the offence by a visit pilgrimage to this City, when I shall expect him to appear forthwith in the costume of a true Lover, with “a blue & sunken eye, a beard neglected, & hose ungartered,” &c &c &c Vanity has a thousand tongues, and at least as many sources of consolation for all her votaries. Thanks to these feminine qualifications of my Comforter, I have not pined away, tho’ you all thrive so well upon my absence -- The girls especially in the very face and eyes of the statutes and common law of friendship, in contempt of all boarding school precepts (not examples) have dared to live & to laugh!! I have nothing I beleive worth telling you of this quarter of the world The City has been dull beyond parallel for four weeks past, & the knowing ones say will continue so ‘till March. The famous Miss Brunson who shoots no arrows but those ‘tipt with gold’ is the Idol of the day -- She is an elegant girl of fashion with more than ordinary beauty and much more than ordinary modesty, for a Belle. Besides she is sensible and amiable. All the qualities are of transcendent brightness in the glare of a splendid fortune. No wonder that the eyes of some weak mortals are dazzled -- Bob goes now and then to see Miss B, and says, that he has bought Mr King’s house on Robinson Street, and that as soon as he has taken leave of his vulgar and friends, the nuptial ceremony is to take Mrs Wilkins (who by is certainly one of the best women in this City), after pronouncing a panegyric on my dear Charles the other evening, which if it didnot make my eyes sparkle with pleasure, made my heart beat with a quicker pulsation, Mrs WilkinsI say, requested me to present her very aff’ly to you -- Your pretty friend Mrs Cadwyck says a thousand civil things of you & by way of a climax as Fannywould say Doctor Mason often enquires after you. Now Don’t be overwhelmedas Fannywouldsay -- -- If I do not write my dear Father tomorrow remember me most tenderly to him and to Mrs Sedgwick -- -- -- To the good for nothing girls, & most particularly to my betrothed -- And do not on any account forget the Heroines of your letter Jenny & Sarah My dear Charles, do reform and write more frequently -- Adieu Heaven bless you Yours most aff'y CMS

N York Feb 4th 1802 Although My Dear Mama I have written once this week I cannot deny myself the pleasure of writing you again I find Mama through your influence )as I suppose) I have at length received a couple of letters I find they had all quite forgotten me except you I knew if you could you would have written me you would My Dear Mama and have informed me how you all were at home Sister has received letters from some one of the family every week and it gives me a great deal of pleasure to read them but Mama I fear I am selfish it is so pleasant to receive letter from persons you love as affectionately as I do the inhabitants of our house I think I am very very much to blame for not having answered Abbys excellent letter but I will write her soon I am very much obliged to Aunt Dwight for the postscript she put in Roberts letter I intended to have written her a letter upon the other side of the sheed but Frances wants to write Do Mama give my love to Robert and Harry tell the I meant to have written them but Mr Watson say that I must not send two letters by one mail Your Dutiful and affectionate Daughter Catharine M S

text: Albany April 20th 1810 Fryday Eve'g I didnot know my dearest Frances till I received your letter today, that Catharine had been seriously ill. Robert mentioned her indisposition, but so slightly that I hardly thought of it a second time. I rejoice indeed in her recovery, but at such a distance our sympathies are feebly affected; it is a humbling fact, that our senses are the avenues to our hearts, we must see the flushed cheek, and hear the groan of anguish before our feelings can be awakened to comprehend even a Mother’s sufferings -- I confess I have sometimes thought of our little Kate’s excessive loveliness with that superstitious pain which dictates the fear that such sweetness cannot be permanent. However in spite of this vulgar presentiment, I trust Kate will one of these days be one of the wisest, best, and happiest matrons in all Christendom. I thank her for her remembrance of her Aunty, beleive me it caused a warmer glow somewhere in the vicinity of my heart, than all the drawing room compliments I ever received. As to Theodore’s prediction about his Aunt Susan I think it is a stronger proof of his tenderness for her than of his possessing cassandrian powers -- I wrote a long letter to my dear Eben a few days since, and intreated his Uncle Hal to bring him to Albany; today we have heard that Eliza and Harry will be here tomorrow, but not a word of my darling boy, so I must relinquish the hope of seeing him -- I wonder my dear Frances if you love him more than I do. Is it your habit and your delight to think of him every night, to wish for him every day? -- You have other Children, I have but one, do not be alarmed at my claiming him. My power over him is that of affection exclusively, & it must yield to the deadening influence of separation, yours cannot. Susan has relinquished all hopes of a New York visit -- We shall be involved in all the hurly burly of moving just at the time that either Bleecker or Sedgwick must be in NYork. Theodore goes the Western Circuit the first of June, in short all of his arrangements would be incompatible with the delightful one of seeing you -- I must take leave of you for the present, we are going to take tea at Mrs Banyer’s if you are not already discouraged you shall have a nocturnal offering -- I found myself so “gravelled for lack of matter” that I determined to depend on the evening for some glimmerings of intellect, but Sue has robbed me of all hope of this nature by the following request -- SheSusan has heard that there is an India ship arrived, and she wishes you to select from its Cargo, cambric of the quality you sent me, enough for two coat dresses, made to wrap with trimmings of the same -- She does not care how cheap you get it provided it is a fine as mine -- 1 yd and 1/2 of fine hook muslin for handkerchiefs -- In addition to what she wants for the dresses, trimmings, &c, she want a yard for I don’t know for what -- Since I am on on the subject of dresses, trimmings &c &c let me thank you for all the trouble you have taken for me, I am perfectly satisfied with every thing and only dissatisfied that I have not in my power to return these favors -- I mentioned to you that I would send the money for the shoes, but I beleive they may as well be charged -- You didnot let me know the price of Mrs Symmes's muslin -- I wish there was some philosophy in vogue that would free us from the slavery of these petty wants -- Nothing less than the “genius of universal emancipation” will affect it, and I am afraid that even this wonder working genius has no microscopic eye to discern the pigmy chains that bind us in this debasing dependence – These aspirations after heroic indifference are nothing more nor less than the consequence of a provoking disappointment of my Mantua maker -- so you see that I am not free from, but irritated by my chains -- You have heard of Miss Thompson my dear Frances, indeed I recollect your volunteering as her champion last summer -- She is a woman I think of much merit and some genius, as a proof of it I will copy for you a little impromptu which she sent me this morning -- She was here last evening, when I returned from a pedestrian excursion, during which I had met a little stranger whose beauty and loveliness had interested me extremely -- The following lines were suggested by the incident. How knows the gentle timid dove, To find its fond & faithful love; The sweet light-loving Lark to rise, As soon as morn unveils the skies; Or Philomel at evening hour, To seek the lone and silent bow’r? Or how the breathing blushing rose, Her fragrant bosom to unclose, To meet, the Sun’s warm genial pow’r, Or lave her in the dewey show’r? Or how the lilly’s slender stem, To bend its bright and snowy gem, In matchless loveliness beside, The meadow’s little silv'ry tide? Tis Sympathy by bounteous Heav'n, To ev’ry mode of being giv'n: That draws each to its destined goal, As if by one informing soul: ‘Twas this the little Frances drew, To fix her artless eyes on you; ‘Twas sympathy of youth & charms, That first impelled her to your arms: And Innocence almost divine, That gave her cherub lip to thine ‘Twas sweet benevolence that prest, Her guileless bosom to your breast, Whose answering purity my fair, Had almost held her ever there -- Now my dear Sister if the pleasure this little offering of Miss T muse, imparted to me was produced by my interest in the incident, or by my vanity, and not from any intrinsic merit it possesses, I beg you will not let your Husband laugh at it, I am bound by all the laws of honor and gratitude to protect its reputation. He may laugh at me as much as he pleases, but he must not point the shafts of ridicule at poor Miss Thompson, who has not vanity (which I have) as a coat of Mail to repel them -- By rights my dear Frances you should be President of the Synod, for you certainly extend your patronage to the whole body of presbyterian divinity -- Your protegé shall be attended to -- I will remember to forget that I heard him preach once, and go to hear him again -- Theodore will call upon him, and if he has a wife Sue will pay her respects to her Thank my dear Bob for his last letter, I will answer it shortly -- You will absolutely get a horror of my folios, so with love to my dear Brother I will bid you good night Yours most affly C M Sedgwick

text: Albany March -- Thursday 1810 If it were not for you my dear dear Eliza I should think I was forgotten by some of my best friends -- Papa has not written me a line -- Harry who I did think in spite of Law books authorship, & elections, would sometimes regret my departure, has not given me a single evidence of it -- Is this kind my dear Sister? I cannot tell how much I am pained by it -- My very heart sickens at the idea of growing less dear to those on whom it has so long confidently reposed for happiness -- To you my dear Eliza I am indebted for a most excellent letter -- I cannot answer it at all as it deserves at present -- We are this evening going to the last Assembly which promises to be very brilliant, and I have snatched a few moments from the time appropriated to dressing, to scribble to you -- Poor Hawley arrived here last night -- He had not heard of his Mother’s death until Theodore told him. He goes on to Deerfield tomorrow Poor fellow! his destitute and friendless condition deserves & I hope excites our commiseration -- I asked him if his prospects at Brookfield were such as he could desire -- He said No, but he feared he could not better them -- I shall send my letter by him to Pittsfield and I hope it will reach you before Lynch leaves Stockbridge -- I wish Laura to send me two pocket handkerchiefs that I left at home and my covered work basket -- I beg that the quinces may come up if possible -- tell my dear Laura I thank her very much for her letter and will write her by Lynch -- Is Mary Root still in Stockbridge and what are her prospects? -- My best love to Aunt Dwight -- Mrs Backus drank tea here last evening in a large party -- She said she feared you had forgotten your Albany friends, and expressed a strong desire to see you Mrs Beer begs you will come up before moving time -- Don’t my dear Eliza think of the roads what are bad roads to a Lady of your good sense, and strong nerves -- As to Eliza the less, her little bones are so well covered, that a little jolting cannot effect her -- My dear Doctor, My dear Miss Fanny, do insist on Eliza’s gratifying all our wishes, and that she can do by simply coming here -- Mrs B too says you must come -- Can you resist all this? -- Matil goes on Saturday or Wednesday -- -- How are dear little Sue’s eyes -- I would give half I am worth to see her -- Kiss my dear Eben for me -- -- -- Yours as ever C M Sedgwick

Stockbridge Novr 30th 1815 -- Only think of it dear Bob, you have been gone seven weeks, and have not written one word to your Aunt who loves you better than all the Boys of your size in Christendom -- No doubt you have been attending to some great affairs, and have forgotten your poor old Aunt. No my dearest Boy I do not beleive a word of it. I dare to say you think every day of Stockbridge, and of your friends and never forget there is nobody in the wide world that loves you better than your own true ‘Aunty’ -- -- To day is Thanksgiving -- You do not know what that is -- well, I will tell you. At the close of the year the Governor of the State tells all the People that they must go to Church and than give thanks to God for all his goodness to us -- particularly for making the sun to shine upon the Earth, and the showers to fall upon it, so that the things that grow are ripened -- Last summer you saw the apples on the trees. Now they are picked, and part of them made into cider, and part of them laid into our cellars to eat -- You saw the wheat, and the rye and corn growing -- It is now all gathered and prepared for us and for our cattle, to eat -- -- Well dear Bob to make a short story of a long one, after Church we have a noble dinner of fat turkeys geese ducks fowls, &c &c besides mince-pies, and apple-pies -- and the Yankey’s glory pumpkin-pies -- and we are all as happy as possible, remembering who it is that has given us all these good things -- We have got a new member into our family since you went away. Mr Pepoon’s little dog Pink he is the cunningest little Creature you ever saw -- he sleeps with Jo, and little Sue calls him Jo’s Baby -- -- Uncle Harry and I brought a little new white horse from Boston as gentle as a lamb, and a charming horse to ride upon -- I know you could ride him very well if you was here -- Do write to me my dear Robert -- Jo sends his compliments to you, and Sarah -- I send you my dear Robert and the other Children a cake -- -- and as much love, and as many kisses as I should give to your darling cheeks -- Give Fanny a good large piece of cake and tell her Aunt Catharine sent it to her -- . Sarah says I must tell you that Pink has got neither ears nor tale and is as fat as butter! -- Good night my dearest Boy -- Oh how I wish I could go up stairs and find you in your place in my bed -- -- Your affectionate AuntC M Sedgwick Uncle Charles does not go, and I cannot send the mince-pies and cake, for which, I am a great deal more sorry, than you can be -- -- Give my best love to Theodore and Eben and ask them if they can tell the number of Turkeys and Geese and pumpkin pies that have been this day devoured in New Hampshire -- Massachusetts & Connecticut _____

Stockbridge Septr 18th 1817.My dear Brother -- I had calculated on Saturday as the earliest probable time for intelligence from you! So that your letter this morning superadded to its legitimate effect the pleasure of a surprise our morning-side was as gay as I expected from the sadness of la Desolée -- I am sincerely sorry for her, sorry that so much goodness should be robbed of its genuine results by the indulgence of hopes that will as probably be gratified, as the wish of the poor little golden trout in the fable, that was possessed with a desire to fly -- -- -- You have the consolation of knowing that you left us, some of us, quite as miserable as you could have been -- You dear Robert are not an ‘offending Adam’ and our Paradise does not ‘envellope and contain celestial Spirits’ -- tho’ there is our dear Charles ! that such Spirits might well hold heavenly converse with -- -- -- We have missed you more than ever, my dear Robert and I am not sure that it will not be wiser for me to deny myself your society wholly. I fear some of the humors of a spoilt child, and am in danger of crying for what I cannot have -- -- -- -- I was interrupted yesterday, and today am interrupted again, so that I must scrawl over a letter . I heard today from M Dwight and if I can find her letter which since I commenced this paragraph I have spent one half hour in seeking, I shall make a copious extract from it -- It relates to our friend C, and describes that blessed Being so beautifully that I cannot forbear sending it to you -- -- -- I know not how I shall accomplish getting to NY this fall -- -- I feel as if it would come about, but how or when I know not -- -- -- Fanny is writing to you -- Charles has written, and Egbert will be spokesman for all the silent ones. -- -- Charles has I beleive sequestered Mary’s letter -- -- -- find it I cannot -- -- M is the only person that has ever come near sounding in his heart -- Charles will never marry, unless some non-pareille should be sent on a mission from Heaven to him -- Many fair ones have issued a congé d’élire for his benefit, but he does not seem in the least disposed to avail himself of any such facilities -- -- What a calamity has fallen upon the literary world in the death of its two great Benefactors, Madame de Stael and Edgeworth -- I think we should all wear a badge of Mourning -- They have a better title to it than half the great Men, whose deaths as well as lives put a whole Country into commotion -- I have given up Mary’s letter in despair -- the amount of it was that the Father has become entirely, blind, has submitted to one excruciating operation, and subsequent confinement in a dark room -- and when the bandages were removed he was yet in total darkness -- Dr Smith advises another operation, and he will not consent to it -- Mary describes C as an angel of Mercy -- E. is 76 -- and for the pittance of existence that can remain to him, he endures so much _____ I hope my dear Robert to hear from you often -- I cannot do without -- -- -- Write any-thing, only write -- God bless you my dearest Brother Ever yoursCMS.

Stockbridge Jan'y 22d 1818 -- Thanks to Him dear Robert who hath blessed your coming in and going out we have heard of your safe arrival in NYork, tho we have yet no official communication on the subject We all mourned over your Hartford Circuit, and are now a little afraid that the vexations attending your return will cast a shade over the visit, whose memory is blessed to us -- It is not perhaps best that we should always glide over smooth waters, though I could wish dear Brother that 'peace' might be commanded wherever it is your destiny to be -- -- -- It was sometime before we recovered our equilibrium after your departure -- Charles returned as sad as if he had performed the last rites to his last friend -- But at length by the aid of that Monitor which Teaches us to change repining into gratitude, and with the help of that good philosophy which tells us in whatsoever state we are, therewith to be content in short by humility as to our deserts, moderation in our wants, and gratitude for our possessions in spite of the withdrawing of that sun in whose beams we had all laughed and rejoiced, we recoverd in a few days our habitual cheerfulness -- -- -- I was afraid that you was not as happy here as you should have been, there were some Circumstances about it that I could have wished different but I could not change them -- -- -- It may prove a blessing to Theodore that your visit happened just at that time -- -- He seems to feel the importance of recovering your good opinion -- I meant to have suggested to you that it might perhaps be best to say very little to Harry and Jane on the subject of Theodore’s misconduct, for it would naturally produce in them feelings, that would make his living with them an unhappiness to them I certainly would-not wish to give them any false impressions, -- but I wish to leave them free from any that Theodore might have a fair chance to win their good opinion -- I cannot but hope that placed under the authority of his Uncles, with the influence of their example and character, and participating the effects of the loveliness of our excellent and beloved Sister, he will benefit as he ought and deserve such advantages -- . I We ought to pity him -- A malignant star reigned over his childhood -- and we my dear Robert, to whom all the ways of providence have been so benignant, whose infancy was so safe, and so blessed, we surely ought to make great allowances for the unhappy circumstances in which Theodore’s character was formed -- You and I know what they were -- -- -- -- I think he may yet be rescued and become an honor to his family -- What happiness is superior to that of saving a fellow Creature, from vice and its horrid train, and making him virtuous and respectable -- This is a critical period for Theodore -- He certainly does possess many qualities that make a very pleasant Inmate -- and his faults seem to me to be those of youth & curable ______ He has gone to Mr Keep’s -- -- -- -- Our Bombay friend called to see us yesterday for the first time since you left us -- He has had all his fine picturesque locks shorn -- and ‘Ichabod, Ichabod’ is written on every hair of his closely shaven crop -- If I had been Madame de Staël I certainly should have wept over such a loss to the fine-arts, or rather I should have said I did -- Mr A enquired very particularly after you, and as he spoke the gleaming of his luminous eye proved how much pleasure you had given him -- Fanny has gone upon a Church Crusade, she left her very best love for you and Jane, and Hal -- How is Mary Jones? -- Do you know whether Mrs Banyer ever received a letter from me? If she didnot, I wish she may be apprised that I wrote one -- I hope to hear from you on Saturday, and very soon from my dear Jenny. As to Harry I never expect to hear from him, ‘tillMrs Elizabeth Rowe’s mode of Correspondence is revived -- -- We are all well -- Love to Aunt Effy -- -- Adieu my dearest Brothers -- May Heaven's best blessings attend you -- Your's everCMS --

Stockbridge Nov' 30' Monday Eve'g -- I have one moment’s time to write to you my dear Brother, and I improve that to thank you for your last kind letter by Mr Bassett -- As our Thanksgiving approaches, the thoughts of our dear distant friends press closer & closer to our hearts -- I wish you were all to be here to participate in our good cheer -- , and to make for us truly a festival of the spirit -- -- In our fervent Thanksgiving we shall remember the dear Brothers and Sister, whose love blesseth us all the year, and whose health and prosperity are among the most valued of our heavenly Father’s gifts. -- Charles and I have been trying to contrive some mode of sending you some mince-pies -- but all our ingenuity has failed -- I hope dear Robert you will think of us on Thursday -- -- The thought of you may cost me a tear -- but there will be no bitterness in it _____ Your last letter surprised me a little, -- There is a beatitude promised to those that ‘wait’ you know, and I expect to realize it, for I shall be perfectly passive _____ Sister F’ is still in Albany -- I expect her down tomorrow. It should not be “small things” dear Robert that render a woman worthy of you _____ I wrote to Jane in a way to make her think I was as ignorant as she -- that your conduct had been ‘suspicious’ no one could deny – Little Fan has been very sick, but is almost well again -- I thank you dear Robert for the Coffee-pot -- I do not need that or anything else as a momento of you -- The thought of you is as much a part of me as the life-blood that flows thro’ my heart _____ ‘Crazy Sue’ is here again -- I have been often struck by a similitude between her and ‘Madge’ in those actions that mark her insanity -- There was a most diverting scene occurred Saturday between her and Fortune I am in quite too great a hurry to do it justice now and I am afraid I shall never think of it again -- Do you know Fortune? -- He is what Mumbet would call a ‘dum Niger’ who lives at Aunt Dwight’s -- : Aunt was sitting in her kitchen, when Sue came in -- Fortune was frying some liver for his supper -- Sue took up a fork in her ‘sans ceremonie’ manner and would have shared with him. Fortune who didnot know her and only knew she was crazy snatched the fork from her and told he would stick it into her if she did not keep her distance -- At this, with the quickness of a Maniac she siezed a hammer and raising her arm as if to knock his brains out said Are you ready to die -- He had just been present at the slaughter of the Col’s ox and since declares that the attitude and manner of Sue convinced him he was to follow the more noble brute. No’ No -- said he -- ‘are you ready to stand before your Judge’ Oh no no -- Well then say just what I say -- If you miss a word a syllable it shall be the last you ever speak -- Say after me -- ‘I am sorry’. ‘I am sorry’ (The poor Creatures responses were in such a panic-voice as to be scarcely audible) ‘I ask your forgiveness’. ‘I ask your forgiveness’ ‘I will never do so again’. I will never do so again ‘Now pray’. ‘Lord God Almighty have mercy on my soul Lord God Almighty have mercy on my soul’ “Forgive this present sin and all my other sins’ -- ‘Forgive this present sin, and all my other sins” “for Jesus Christ’s sake” “for Jesus Christs sake “Amen”. “Amen” -- -- . 'Now said she laying down her hammer and resuming her fork you look such as you will in Heaven, as white as a cambric handkerchief -- -- Aunt determined to see the scene out without interfering sat at quietly by, and she declares Fortune was as white “in streaks” as he can be in Heaven -- -- I recd my shoes by Mr Burrall -- They suit me exactly -- You are mistaken about my letters to Mrs B -- I have written to her but twice since she went from here -- and have made but a single request of her, and that was to send some patterns for our Society -- I think your mistake must have originated in Eliza’s having transferred some commissions to her Cynthia is here and sends her love to you remember me aff’y to all, and tell Theodore and Egbert we all wish very much they were to join us at our Thanksgiving -- God bless you all my dear Robert -- Beleive me as ever thineCMS _____ How are Harry's eyes?

Stockbridge July 7th1807 By this time my dear Frances is initiated into all the complicated ceremonies of the Beau Monde. I confess I do not think there is much danger of your being intoxicated, with the pleasures that are hourly soliciting your acceptance, I rather fear that you will conjure up a thousand phantoms in the shape of burns, scalds, drownings, falls, and sickness indeed calamity in every form, that it ever appeared to the sickness loving imagination of Aunt Sergeant, to frighten away all that wears the aspect of enjoyment I hope better things of you my dear Sister, and as I think you possessed of reason, and some little rationality, I trust you will beleive my assurances of the welfare of our little flock -- If it were not too trite; and I think provoking an observation, I should say they were much better without than with you -- Hannah is extremely attentive and kind -- Theodore and Eben have lost their truant disposition, as to their improvement in erudition, I know nothing. Theodore told me yesterday with an air of vast complacency, that he read in Anchor: From this I should suspect he had made a retrograde movement. He has with wonderful facility transferred his affections from you to me, for the time being -- -- Little Kate has never cried one night since you “left” -- She sometimes wakes during the night -- -- Her bowels are not at all disordered and her teeth do not give her any trouble ______ Your old friend Thomas Day, What old Tom,? no your Tom? aye, has beg been here ever since nine in the morning. just as I was dating my letter, my temper was somewhat ruffled by his sudden appearance. Now at two Oclock are going to dinner, and I have proceeded but just so far in my letter. He has made a day of it in the old Connecticut style. I wish in my heart you were at home, that you might with the chosen friend of your Youth, summon up “the Ghosts of your departed joys” -- I intended to have given you and Papa an epistle of “much pith and moment” but alas! my good intentions are always frustrated -- -- Mama:has been much more comfortable for the last four days and nights. She has had none of those distressing turns during the day, neither has she for several nights -- -- -- -- She rides regularly every day, and I know it is of essential service to her Tomorrow we hope for a “consummation, most fervently to be wished” from New York -- -- -- -- -- -- I wish Frances, if it is perfectly convenient to Papa you would request him to purchase the Minstrel and Mrs Montagu’s essay on the genius of Shakespear -- -- -- -- -- Remember us all most affectionately to Papa -- To the MrsT family my best love -- -- -- -- Yours &c my dear Sister CMS

Stockbridge July 17th 1816 If you have written to me three times dear Susan since I have written to you, one must have been shipwrecked instead of arriving at the haven, where it would have been so gladly hailed -- For those I have received I thank you most heartily, and gratefully Mrs Backus and her party arrived here yesterday afternoon -- We were all absent, Charles at New Marlborough, Fanny at Church-meeting, and I with poor Aunt West _____ however I returned in time to give them tea, and as gracious a welcome as real pleasure could produce -- I was very sorry they left us so soon -- . -- I cannot tell you how much satisfaction I have in knowing you are again in Albany -- -- I feel as if we had got you home -- -- Depend upon it dearest Sue I havenot the slightest disposition to forget my promise but shall in due time perform it according to the letter and the spirit of it -- We are in ‘six troubles, yea, in seven’ -- -- Aunt West after a trial as impassioned as almost any in the annals of politics, is condemned -- most unrighteously, thirty against her, eleven for her -- The question was from the beginning, whether Mr Swift should fall, or the victim be immolated on the altar he had set up -- The people are determined to sacrifice every thing to their Idol, and to the jacobinic pleasure of exercising their power against “the great folks” -- -- But dear Sue I forget that you are removed from the sphere of interest, and cannot sympathize with the feelings that have rent our peaceful little society -- You will be happy to hear that Doctor West has been enabled to show to us all, that his part is with Him who has overcome the world, and that his Master’s strength has been sufficient for him in his extremity, so that he has not once departed from the strict line of christian love and sufferance -- -- -- I thank you for executing my commissions -- -- The shoes suit perfectly well -- -- -- Mrs Brown has lost her youngest child -- She died very suddenly and unexpectedly after three days illness -- Mrs Brown as in all her troubles has a quiet spirit -- -- I think I never could mourn the departure of an infant excepting from the pang of parting with it -- They escape from a tempestuous ocean, and receive an immortal existence upon easy terms -- -- It has always seemed to me that Children must be a beautiful portion of the Redeemer’s kingdoms, somewhat analogous to the birds in our the natural creation -- Charles left several articles here, which I will send by the first opportunity -- -- Mrs Backus gave me a fine account of you all, I should infer from it that you had been a pilgrimage to the temple of Hygeia -- -- -- I intend to go to Albany as soon as I hear that your Aunt is gone, I never expected to make this a condition -- Remember dear Sister to all your household, and beleive me ever truly yoursCMS --

New York Feb 3rd 1802 Another Mail arrived and poor Catharine hasnot received a line from you it seems to me impossible that you can have forgotten me entirely. Can my short absence have entirely eradicated that affection which My Dear Papa once felt for me No I will not believe it Sure you sometimes think of your Catharine who every morning had a kind kiss imprinted on her Cheeks by her Dear Papa but I hope in future you will not forget to write me. You still Papa give us a feint hope that we shall have the pleasure of seeing you this winter but I fear we shall have to give it up. Mr Watson says every night when we sit down to supper that he wishe you were here to partake of it with us it is not he only that wishes it but we all join our wishes to his We have had quite winter weather here for this two or three days and I think it promises snow I hope My Dear Papa you will bring one of the Boys with you Mr Watson send his respects to you he is very much obliged to you for attending to Mumbets coming here he wishes to have her come on as soon as possible. The Family are all well and desire to be remembered to you. You see Papa for all they promised as well as I did they have not been so punctual in writing as I have. Do remember Papa what what pleasure it gives me to receive letters from you and write your Dutiful and affectionate Daughter Catharine M Sedgwick

Albany March 7th 1816 It is not in the nature of woman to have nothing to say, & certainly not in mine to have nothing to say to you dear Frances, yet sorrowful to say I have been turning my eye inward on vacancy for ten minutes, -- At last I have come to the wise conclusion, that words being the signs of ideas, I may as well fill up my paper, and trade like your banks upon a fictitious Capital -- -- I am sure at any rate of conveying to you a great deal of pleasure by the enclosed letter, for our dear Eliza always writes, as if her heart was kindled with the holy fire -- -- She has been very much afflicted by Theodore’s affair -- It is certainly not so much bad as it might have been -- -- But there is nothing, to a Mother, above all to a christian Mother so heart-piercing as the unworthiness of a Child -- -- Theodore has so much volatility that you can hardly trust to the best impulses -- -- He is affectionate and submissive I think the Doctor in his treatment of him has strongly proved the best influence of religion upon his character -- He has been consistent, mild, forbearing and forgiving -- -- Theodores punishment was certainly disproportioned to his offence. The principal fault alledged was proved not to be true -- -- -- However I presume Eliza has detailed to you all the circumstances _____ May you my dear Sister be spared this trial of your patience -- -- -- -- I know no family so much blessed in all its circumstances as this -- -- Health & competence; & love; assured and sanctified by the precious covenant of faith -- -- -- -- Theodore is making great progress -- Maria is very interesting but poor little Soul, this world does not smile upon her as upon her Brother --; to him it is all sunshine -- -- He is so happily constituted, that his joyous heart vibrates music to every influence -- Maria is as sensitive as your little Robert, and I think very much like him, they both seem destined to go thro’ their pilgrimages, “groaning, being burthened” -- -- -- -- I find that my friends in NYork all expect me there this Spring -- but much as I desire to see them, I hardly think I shall go down. -- -- I cannot say with certainty, because with all the inducements I have to go, and the facilities I shall have when the steamboat goes three times a week I have not much confidence in my courage to abide by a self-denying resolution -- I shall expect to see you soon at any rate -- -- My dearly beloved Brother Robert, the very thought of him is enough to shake the firmest resolutions -- On the whole I will be wise enough to take no thought for the moment -- -- Would you tell R. that since I have been writing I have received his letter by Dr P Clarke, and shall write to him very soon -- I want you my dear Sister to get me 1/2 yard of nice india mull muslin -- for worked ruffles -- I would not have it unless it can be obtained more reasonably there, than here, the only good piece here is six dollars -- I should be glad to have R send it to me, by the first opportunity -- -- -- -- Robert will be kind enough to pay for it, & charge it to account -- -- Susan sends her love you all -- -- . Do my dear Frances when you write again, send some word of remembrance to Mr B -- He is always asking about you and hardhearted as you think me I often wish it was in my power to chase the ‘foul fiend’ from his melancholy face by some kind proof of your regard -- Eloise says that Mr W is coming up the river, I hope here, -- I have no pleasure in expectation that would be a parallel to seeing him -- I trust my dear Sister the time will soon come when we shall again enjoy together, the freedom and fulness of personal intercourse -- ‘Till then, & always the Father of mercies bless you & yours dear Sister, YoursCMS Mrs Symmes wishes you to ask Sally Jay to purchase her a black Merino shawl, two yards square, a border all around (not mantle fashion) -- She would like to have it at 28 dollars, certainly not to exceed 30 -- She will forward the money as soon as she knows how much it is, and she would be glad of it, as soon as it can be sent -- -- -- -- -- -- -- She has parted with the one Miss Watts bought, because she feared it would be thought too gay for her

Stockbridge August 18th 1817My ain dear Sister Jane -- All my heart flows forth in one longing wish that you were here, not only because you can make ‘life’s cup of pleasure’ sparkle far below the ‘brim’ -- but I fear my dearest Jenny the effect of this oppressive heat upon you I wonder at my own stupidity in not laying out my whole strength to keep you when you was here. I took it for granted that you must go, and tho’ the necessity cost me many a heart ache, I didnot try to prevent it -- -- I hope you bathe frequently in the salt water, that I beleive is the best mode of enabling you to endure the heat -- Harry being in the City is inevitable and therefore not so deplorable -- -- Beside he has more health than you -- -- -- And now dear Sister let me thank for your kind letter by Robert -- -- -- We were not born Sisters dear Jane, but can the bond of nature produce any thing more tender than that sentiment expressed by the gentle Ruth, “thy God shall be my God, and thy Country my Country” -- -- -- Of what import is it that we sprang from different sources, like the streams that mingle their waters, and flow into the bosom of the ocean, we dear Jane in unity of spirit will finish our course here, and when the terrestrial shall become celestial, we shall I trust be associated in the joys and glories of immortality -- -- -- We have gone on very smoothly since you left us -- Je crois que le crise est passé avec la petite Veuve -- Elle deviènt raisonnable! She has determined to remain here ‘till our return from the Springs. Une grande felicité pour Susanne! -- -- We go on Thursday -- -- I shall write to you from there, an I shall probably see enough of fashion and her handmaid folly to amuse you -- -- Frances has, gone went to Lebanon to pass Sunday with her Husband -- Our friend Mrs Jones <! -- Frances Jones is a guess --> is here from Albany and to my sorrow her Brother Harry. Just after I began to write he sent me word that Mr Jones was below but I have persevered and will finish my letter in spite of him -- Mrs Jones says you are a ‘Sorceress’-- I should think so too if I didnot it possible that even such effects as you have produced might proceed from natural causes -- You have taken all hearts captive from “Lady Margaret’s to Goosie Gibbie’s” -- -- -- -- I have heard from Eloise at Boston -- She seems in Spirits and as well as when she left us -- She hadnot seen Louisa but she had seen Mr Roland! -- -- -- Poor Eliza yet groans “being burdened” -- -- her tribe are all well -- -- -- I have had too a most charming letter from our friend Edward <! -- Could be Edward Channing -->, in which he speaks as it is meet he should of you -- -- -- I beleive I have treated Mr Jones with assez de nonchalance I thank you for the faithful execution of my commissions -- Eliza wishes to know how much you gave for her coffee pot -- as it is a present from her Sister Fanny -- My love to you dear Harry -- Aunt Effy’s to both -- -- -- Charles says ‘oh my beloved Sister Jenny Minot’ Adieu dearest YoursCMS -- What should I do without your hat!

Stockbridge July 15'th1807 I have just completed my daily task by lulling my little Kate to sleep; and giving my "good nighty' kiss to my sturdy Boys; who are just now fast locked in the arms of their hugging friend Morpheus. To an absent and affectionate Father no picture of his children in any point of view, can be presented to him, that is not interesting -- Whether they are painted climbing the trees, driving their hoops or “with shining morning face, creeping like snails unwillingly to school” (the latter we must all confess would not be a very unfair representation of your tardy Sons) is a matter of indifference -- . But to those who are blessed in their dear society, and consequently condemned all day to the clattering of their heels, and the more intolerable clattering of their tongues their sleeping, are their preeminently charming moments. However my dear Mr Watson to square my conduct by the golden rule of “doing as I would be done by” in justice to my dear little charges, I should tell you that in the absence of their legal protector, they are the best Children in the world! Obedient, and quiet; which by the way are the two first virtues I should inculcate -- -- My little namesake, and your favorite suffered nobly in the deprivation of her accustomed nourishment -- Frances feared some bad effects might result from it, and I believe half a dozen words favoring her opinion would have induced her to defer weaning her until Autumn. Luckily every body (for with the affectionate solicitude of a Mother she consulted all ages and sexes) encouraged her to persevere, and I think she has on no occasion displayed more fortitude than when she parted from us -- To a person of ordinary feeling an absence of three weeks, would not have been an affair of the most melancholy nature, but for her with all her apprehensions, and her apprehensions generally amount to convictions, it was a magnanimous effort -- -- -- You charged me most particularly with regard to the Boys attending School, they apparently have lost entirely their truant disposition, although I confess they do not evince much ardor in literary pursuits -- Catharine does not yet articulate any words I hope she is not to be denied the privilege of her sex -- -- -- -- Theodore brought Eliza down from Albany. He made no communications on the subject that has so long interested us, but from the excellent state of his health and spirits, that hisI should judge his affairs were in the most favorable train for a permanent adjustment -- -- nothing untoward from the decision of our lovely friend , if she was to be guided by the dictates of her own feelings -- -- Mama continues stationary -- She desired me to give her love to you and tell that you must on no account fail to come to Stockbridge this fall. She rarely expresses as much as this -- -- Adieu my dear Mr Watson beleive Catharine Sedgwick

Stockbridge October 4th1811 My desk and I are friends again since the general dissension; & my pen has got such an inveterate habit of beginning Dear Robert, that it does its duty with very little impulse from my heart, or rather I should say it requires very little -- Judge Benson has just completed his tour of gallantry, he arrived here yesterday, after having deposited Miss Russell safely in Boston, & brought the pretty & the dangerous Miss Eggleston home -- Harry has probably detailed to you a conversation he had with the Judge in consequence of some declarations the Judge made at Theodore’s table -- I am not surprised that his want of discernment should make him a victim to Mrs S’s superior sagacity -- Heaven grant that she may not extend her blasting influence to a mind & heart more dear to us -- From all that I can learn she has been very successful in prejudicing some of her Boston friends against Harry -- ‘The Children of this world' are indeed my dear Robert 'very wise in their generation’ ; but meanness & malice cannot have any triumph that we need dread over true nobility of soul. After all when my resentment subsides, I can pity the tumults of a conscience that never whispers peace, & the conflicts of a heart that has no sacred rest for virtue -- The miserable half gratification of an insatiate vanity, & the bustle of impertinent trifling make up the sum total of Mrs S’s happiness. If this is true & every day’s observation proves it, is not she an object of commiseration? -- Let us together my dearest Robert, thank our God, that that purity which is now sainted in Heaven, shed its blessed influence on the formation of our characters, & early taught us to love the light of virtue & the favor of Heaven -- May the memorial of her excellence, the treasured recollection of her patient endurance of every evil preserve us from even a momentary forgetfulness of our filial duty. That duty must be paramount to all earthly ones, & it is made easy & delightful to us by the parental virtues of the best of Fathers -- If we do rightMrs S cannot invade the sacred circle of our happiness, but my dear Brother in order to attain this great end, we must place our chiefdependence, on the guidance of that Power that will assuredly save those from temptation, that pray to him for this preservation Forgivenessof injuries is the first precept of that Gospel which is to bring peace to the world; let this be our peace, and the blessing of God will rest upon it -- Catharine has written me twice since she left here, letters that prove she has more sensibility than I ever suspected her to be the possessor of -- Poor Girl: her air-built castles have had a sudden & dreadful annihilation, she won’t now willingly I believe sacrifice all her promised scenes of cottage bliss on the shrine of any Widower’s genteel establishment -- Subsistence and comfort have at length displaced the favorite words in her vocabulary, starvation & rapture -- As the chief end of Woman is to be married, I should be very glad to see Catharine in that desirable condition -- She would grace many situations, & certainly not disgrace any -- Do not neglect to write her as you would hope to have your own Sister treated with kindness in the like solitary predicament -- It is impossible to calculate the chances of this warfare, but if singleness should be my destiny, I pray that I may have dignity enough to give up the world before it gives me up -- -- While it pleases Heaven to continue the lives of my dear Brothers no state has terrors for me -- I began this letter last week to send by Hopkins, & now I am obliged very hastily to finish it -- Frances is tolerable, except in her spirits & they, I think are improving -- -- -- My dear Robert do write me often nothing delights me more than your letters. -- Love to Mr Watson & all my newYork friends who are kind enough tosay they value it, never forgetting sweet Gertrude -- Adieu dear Brother -- Heaven bless you C M Sedgwick
