text: Stockbridge Thursday Evening -- 1811 Dear Robert, I have been tortured this two days by knowing there was a letter for me from you at Hudson, and that I must wait two days longer, before I can get it fairly within my grasp -- Our Countrymen are so careful of the coats they “go down to York” in that they will not wear the pockets by bringing a letter in them, but they must be deposited in their trunks, which must be left at Hudson, to be brought in by any Chance waggon -- Now my dear Bob is not this a trial worthy the endurance of patriarchal patience? Patience is not a virtue in vogue & therefore I have adopted the more modern consolation of tragic lament, and true Grecian (or as Miss Thompson would call it attic) scolding -- In the latter accomplishment I think I might rival the great Mother of the Art, Xantippe herself -- Charles and myself have just returned from making a primitive visit at Uncle Doctor’s -- It is wonderful my dear Robert that a family desolated as this is, by disease in its most appalling shapes, should have kept alive their social spirit, & maintained thro’ every difficulty the most generous hospitality -- In this instance as in many other benevolent allotments of Providence, that are constantly before our eyes; to the infliction of evil, is opposed the bestowment of blessings, that in their very nature are best calculated to counteract the influence most to be dreaded from those calamities -- Our good Uncle is dear to us for his own excellence, but he excites a more tender sentiment from his resemblance to our dear Mother -- She had more sensibility & therefore more liberality, & more general tenderness, but in that blessed virtue, that “hopeth all things, & endureth all things” they both have most perfectly exemplified the Christian character -- You who live with multitude my dear Robert know very little of the power of sympathy, in our limited Circle, where every birth, marriage, & death, is known, & consequently as far as fellow feeling goes, we have a perfect community of joys & sorrows, -- I felt this very strongly the other day at the Funeral of poor Elnathan Curtis -- He came here with his wife & children on a visit to his friends, & was seized with the typhus fever, which very soon put an end to his life -- I beleive he was about Harry’s age. My heart ached when I thought that it was even possible that my dear Brothers, in all the vigor of health, & joy of youth, might be thus suddenly wrested from me -- Judgment has as yet passed by us, & the tender mercies of our Heavenly Father have rested with us. It cannot be always thus but may “God’s will be done” be the language of our lips, and out hearts -- -- Frances and the Baby are both improving daily -- Frances arrangements must now be governed entirely by her Husband, who we shall expect early in the next week -- Without him she will never resolve to leave the Child, it is impossible now for any one to say, what her best plan would be Your little namesake is now ‘Lord of the ascendant’ in my estimation, & has insensibly stolen Eben’s birthright to the first place in my heart Your Cravats & shirt & stockings are ready for you, but I am afraid to trust them to Williams, as he is notoriously careless of everybody’s affairs but his own -- Maj Brown goes next week, & by you shall have them -- We have no news except a projected jaunt of Harry’s and Charles’s; they intend making the Circuit of Connecticut, by way of a little dissipation this winter -- The heads & members of the northern department are all in good health & sound heart -- -- YourMary spends the Winter with Mrs Seymour, in all the dignity & interest of retirement -- -- -- Dear Charles is as he always was the best & loveliest of human beings -- -- Indeed take us bye & large dear Bob we are a very clever little set of people here -- -- Good night. Heaven bless you -- Ever yours C M S

Albany March 12th 1813 I have not been insensible to your kindness my dear Frances, in having notwithstanding the incessant demands on your time, written to me since your return, nor have I been unaffected by the tenderness of your letter -- But my mind has been harrassed by circumstances which I could not treat with the contempt they have deserved -- These petty trials my dear Frances corrode my temper, and enervate my mind, and leave me mortified with my irresolution and ashamed of my weakness Self-knowledge is the best teacher of humility -- . And Tho’ we think we are fortified for every event, we find our most vigorous resolutions and our most ardent aspirations after excellence, are the victims of the first occasion that tests them -- It is this sad experience of our own weakness, which impels us to pray for that strength which is sufficient for all our necessities -- -- -- I have been led to these reflections by retracing my life for the last four years, in which I find much to deplore, and very much to be forgiven -- -- -- -- Mrs Sedgwick and Harry left Stockbridge last Friday -- -- Mrs S for some time before her departure expressed her dissatisfaction with the provision made for her -- -- By giving her reason up to her ruling passion, she removed the slight veil that hid the deformity of her heart -- -- She has even said in so many words, that she had made no money by marrying, that she had lived a life of slavery, and got nothing for it at last -- Such expressions betraying her object and her disappointment, have been poured into the ears of servants that despised her -- Not one tender feeling has appeared, to soften or alleviate the bitterness of her mortification -- -- This is wretchedness without hope and without help, such as the severest human justice could not inflict, but yet where you have no sympathy, you cannot have much compassion -- -- -- -- -- -- Before Mrs S went away she confined herself almost entirely to her own room, never joining the family except for a little while at dinner -- We never varied nor abated in our respect and kindness to her, but where there is no heart, it is in vain to try to reach it -- I should not my dear Frances have thought it worthwhile to mention these painful circumstances to you, if I had not thought it necessary for you to regulate your feelings a little more by the rules of prudence -- Your letter to Mrs S at the same time that it exhibited your strong and admirable sensibility, proved how little that sensibility was at the time under the control of your reason and experience -- Surely if you had remembered the coldness and the vanity of Mrs S you would not have thrown away such pearls upon her -- -- Besides my dear Sister you involved us all in the obligation you assumed -- Surely it is not our duty to love such a woman as Mrs S -- -- -- If you had felt as I have all my patience necessary to be merely forbearing and gentle towards her, you would will not wonder that I was startled by the promises of your letter -- We willnot withhold from her one tittle that our veneration for our beloved Father requires of us, more we ought not to do -- -- Your last letter on the subject of furniture was another proof of the delicacy and generosity of your temper -- I do not know my dear Frances, how the house could be kept open, and the family made comfortable if the furniture should be divided -- Still if Eliza wishes it, it must be done, and your part might furnish your own room and benefit you while it benefited us, -- -- Our plan for the Summer provided you approve of it, is to keep an accurate account of every expense, and at the termination of the season each one is to defray their proportion -- -- Charles of course will contribute his part in giving us the use of his House &c. Susan intends going down early in the season -- -- I wish you would let me know when you intend coming up, and if you approve this arrangement -- -- I neednot tell you how much it would gratify me to go to NYork this Spring -- But the cares of housekeeping will occupy so much of my time this Summer, and so much must be devoted to preparations, that I have no time to spare -- -- -- I am afraid my dear little Bob has forgotten me. -- I hope my dear Sister you will keep me in the remembrance of all the Children -- I love them nearly as much as if they were my own -- -- Susan is yet quite feeble, very much troubled with indigestion The Baby thrives very well with the aid of the bottle Theodore is a charming boy -- Mrs Symmes begs me to make her kindest love to you all -- My best love to my Brothers and Eloise -- -- God bless you and yours my dearest Sister Everyours affy CM Sedgwick

Stockbridge Novr 16th 1817. Besides a large debt of love, I owe you dearest Jane, an acknowledgement of your last kind letter, which like all your letters diffused a bright beam of gladness throughout our dwelling -- -- I write with more tranquility than I have been able to do for sometime to my NewYork friends -- The long agony of indecision is over; I am no Philosopher on the endurance of evil, but like all the vulgar throng, I can submit to what is inevitable -- -- I am now sincerely sorry I didnot go to NYork -- It never occurred to me that I might have gone now and next Spring too. I feared the cold weather, which the continual vexatious pain in my head unfits me to encounter -- -- I do not know what possessed Charley to intimate that I felt scrupulous in relation to Mrs Banyer -- -- I had received every assurance that was necessary from her -- -- The friendship of such a Being once obtained, all subsequent suspicion and doubt is worse than useless -- Now dear Sister a long winter must elapse before I see any of you. I pray that it may not be a ‘Winter of discontent’ to me -- -- -- You have had a delightful time with William and Louisa -- -- When you write the latter do tell her that I am very grateful to her for her kind invitation to Boston. All my intercourse with her has been a series of favors on her part and gratitude on mine -- Theodore is with us now, he came down on Thursday, and we hope to detain him ‘till next Thursday -- But he is wedded to the homestead, and takes the command literally that says to the married man He shall forsake all others and cleave to her alone -- -- I begin to feel very stingy of my Brothers dear Jenny. I think I had better keep Robert and Charles to comfort me; for I do not like the idea of walking alone thro’ this vale of tears. When Bob is married I shall have to put up the prayer of good old Simeon. ‘Now let thy servant depart in peace,” fore all after will be solitude and sadness -- -- -- We do not live so far out of the world, as to be uninterested in its fashions and follies -- There are none of the great ends of dressing to be attained in Stockbridge -- but still the sin of Mother Eve ‘cleaveth unto us,’ -- -- It is then in obedience to this law of my nature that I ask you to tell me what is to be the fashion of coats for the winter? and whether of cloth or silk? how the dresses are made? whether what ruffs are worn? and anything else that your own infirmities will indicate I shall want to know -- -- I have no news to tell you -- Our lives are not adorned with a circumstance; -- Charles has made his cider & I have made my applesauce we have put up our Curtains and corked our windows and are prepared to burrough for the Winter -- -- Do dear Sister enliven our solitude as often as you can by your letters -- Let them be, as they will, in all respects save one like ‘Angel’s visits’ -- -- not ‘far between’ – How do you find Harry as a Housekeeper You know I always boasted his tallents as a Provider, but as he despises tea, you cannot yet put them to the test -- Sister Fanny sends her best love to you and Hal -- She wishes you to be good enough to purchase for her, and send by Mr Williams a little Book entitled “Grammar of Geography, by Jacob Willett” The Children all send their love to you; you are one of their models of perfection -- They are good Children and will I think be a great comfort to their Mother -- -- God bless you my dearest Jane -- YoursC M S . .

Stockbridge Saturday evening Nov' 1818 -- The habit of writing often to you my dear Brother seems to engender the want -- It will be hard, if my habits become your plagues ‘till they do, I shall indulge them to my hearts-content-- Mr ‘Ball and Bassett’ has not yet returned, when he does, I trust we shall have some return to the mail we sent by him. Arrivals from your quarter are as anxiously looked for here as any arrival in the Isle of Sky -- The anticipation serves us for a topic at breakfast, dinner, & tea, for a week at least -- The letters we write come in with a thousand other matters of interest, and are like traces on the sand, effaced as soon as made. Is it not so? -- -- I hear from Eliz’ yesterday -- She says “I cannot delay transmitting through you to your Brother Robert an acknowledgement of the receipt of a beautiful Edition of Byron’s works, which he sent me by Papa. Will you say to him that they will be classed among my valuables, of incidental as well as intrinsic worth; but tho’ the books are so very elegant and Byron a favorite Poet his little note beginning “Dear Coz” was worth them all. When he shall have found a Lady, whom he deems worthy to participate his existence (of which he confesses there is not an impossibility) with her, perhaps, I may have the pleasure of depositing my goodwill to her better half” -- a pretty long quotation -- I would have saved myself the trouble and given you the pleasure of reading her whole letter, if I had any other conveyance than the Mail -- While I am on the subject of letters, I will tell you that I rec’d quite a long and pleasing one last week from Miss Dillingham -- She says “the Abbe Sicard affirms that Mr Clerc must return to Paris in the Spring” -- so that I suppose our Deaf & Dumb must then lose his valuable services. Probably, he is to be the successor of the old Abbe, who is 72. What a blessing it is that there is a wisdom that can make even the dumb eloquent -- I do not know when I have been more impressed with the degradation, of making the whole Being subserve the purposes of mere animal wants than when I was at Cornwall . A child had been taken to the asylum from a family there, as a charity Scholar -- -- Her friends were deploring the necessity of suffering her to remain in the school, because she “would not know nothing about business” and her old Grandmother said, would be ‘just like any Lady good for nothing at all’. Timothy’s coronation day occurs on Wednesday. The meeting of the allies in the Champs Elyces or any other grande circonstance, could not be more magnificent than is this in the eye of the Hero of the scene. He seems determined to indemnify himself for the loss of the organ of sight, by magnifying every object to his mental vision -- He has summoned no less than ten Clergymen, and as many delegates to compose his Council, besides sending letters of invitation far & near to his acquaintance. Green River must enlarge her boundaries, if the North does not keep back & the South refuse to give up half he has invited -- I have never quite made up my mind whether vanity was the greater torment or comfort, but I rather think its gratifications have all the unsatisfactioness of fictions, & its disappointments are very sober uncertainties -- Such a Man as W. continually walketh in a 'vain show', and tho’ palaces may glitter, & Goddesses stalk around him …thuriel’s spear in some form or other is continually dissolving the baseless fabrics, and leaving all a waste -- -- Who would not prefer the Inheritance of one of the beatitudes that are promised to the Disciples of the meek & Jesus! -- -- We are all well, or mending – Little Charles Pomeroy has been very sick with a swelling under the knee -- We were very anxious for some days, but he has been lanced, and he is quite relieved -- Charles is sleeping profoundly on the Sofa. He charged me to leave space enough for a postscript -- which I am the more willing to do as it is Saturday night, when you may remember Greek instead of a kind Nurse, is always a Tyrant -- Good-night dearest Robert. May you have such visions as good health and conscience at peace with all man can bestow _____

Stockbridge July 2nd 1813 There is hardly a joy or a sorrow passes before me dear Robert, that I do not bear it on my mind to you, and yet how seldom have you the record of it -- -- -- I suppose that you will think that affection, like the Frenchman’s pity should have some visible effect, and would rather say ‘love me a letter’ than that I should love you with a love passing that of woman -- -- I am not myself an admirer of love in the abstract -- or a Beleiver in the passions agitating and swelling the fountain of love, the heart, unless I can see the evidence flowing from it in streams of benevolence and kindness. I may be a partial judge in my own case, but I do think my dear Brother, that as some of the pleasantest excursions my fancy ever takes are when it hovers about you, that as my mind delights to rest upon the hours when we have taken ‘sweet counsel together’ and to contemplate your amusement & happiness in life, and above all, your blessedness in eternity. I have some proof that I do love you, with a love surpassing at least the ordinary love of woman -- -- The plants of affection were rooted in our hearts in the spring of life. They were nurtured by the precepts, and examples of the tenderest parents. They were blessed by Him, who hath promised his blessings to families dwelling together in love, & they will I trust grow up into a tree whose branches shall overshadow us, when this world, and the glory of it has passed away -- -- There is everything dear Robert in our past experience to endear us to each other -- -- May we not reasonably hope that we are still the peculiar care of those who are removed from our sight, at least it cannot be wrong to indulge such a belief, and as we are the creatures of second causes, it may incite us to a more vigilant performance of our duties to each other -- Would not it dear Brother make us more gentle & forbearing, more generous & sympathetic, watchful for every occasion of showing kindness & doing good, and more careful to avail ourselves of them -- -- -- I never should have been a Catholic for I never should have endured voluntary penance -- I escape from their similitude as I would from monsters. Since your kind explanation, I have not thought again of the subject -- It is not worth thinking of except as it may suggest augment our gratitude for the strong defenses about our hearts, against Invaders as distrust and suspicion -- You know the features of our little world dear Robert are seldom discomposed by the turbulence of passion, and not very often animated with the smile of joy -- -- -- There is a “daily beauty” in our dear Eloises life which tho’ it might not shine on the page of the Poet, certainly does diffuse a very sweet light around us, -- The Doctor I think already experiences the benefit of his confession He appears more mild and affectionate than I have ever known him. Miss Fanny is now with them, and has as ever “a still small way” of doing great things for others -- The Boys and Girls are as happy as freedom, health, & pretty good consciences can make them. Poor Charles is yet quite sick with the inflammation in his hand, whether it has a felonious intent, we cannot yet ascertain -- -- -- I rejoice my beloved Brother, that you feel the importance & efficacy of that religion which alone can give us peace in this world and life in the next. I long to see you give your testimony of your acceptance of the forgiving love of our Master -- -- Our souls are his, and shall we not freely sacrifice him the best affections and services of our hearts -- bearing forth our love & and proving by our confidence and obedience that we are no longer outcasts from his family -- -- God grant of his infinite Mercy that we may all touch the garment of our Saviour’s righteousness and be made whole -- -- I hope to hear from you very soon -- I do not deserve your prompt return, but alas dear Bob, our wants generally bear an awful disproportion to our deserts -- Tell my dear Sister that I am heartsick for her arrival -- and I do hope that in pity to the Children she will not much longer delay coming -- You know there is a bone of contention between Eloise and I, but I cannot choose but love her in the midst of all my growling -- Remember me to all my friends & particularly to Mr W, F, & the Children. Charles sends his best love -- -- Yours always dear Robert CM Sedgwick

text: New York Decr 15th1810 I could not resist a certain impulsive motion towards my pen, when I heard that Gen’lW was going this Evening, & I involuntarily began to address my dear Charles -- I cannot say that I should not have done it with malice prepense, but the fact is I did it without any prepense at all. If I do not write more than ten lines, & those not worth the reading, forgive me dear Charles, in consideration of an intolerable headache, stupidity & as I am no philosopher,. I deny the doctrine that pain is no Evil, & hold that an effect must follow a cause, & that if I have a headache, I must have a heart-ache too -- -- I presume our friend Mrs Forbes has long before this dispelled the “dark clouds” that shrouded her purpose, & made you all stare & gape with amazement -- I think we shall soon get so accustomed at Stockbridge to the most 'wonderful wonder that the world ever wondered at' that they will be no more strange to us than the rising or setting of the Sun -- We will write a new play which shall annihilate the separation of the rival Mothers & the rival Queens, and all of the rival Strangers And if you please dear Charles we will have an underplot. We There shall be a young man in all the pride of self confidence conquered at the very moment that he is boasting his security against the whole artillery of a young Lady’s charms -- You must supply me with the detail of incidents, & I will furnish the denouement. -- -- We often wish my dear Brother that you was here, to partake in some of our pleasures & to confer a great deal of happiness But after all there is no place like that home that is adorned & blessed with the presence of our beloved Parent. -- -- I have just received Papa’s letter -- I am sincerely sorry that the Judge left my letter for I think it might have been of service in guarding Papa -- I am extremely concerned to hear of Mrs Sedgwick’s indisposition, tell my dearest Papa, & tell Ms her, that if I am sure I could be of service & comfort to them, & that if they wish it I will come home at any time -- There are persons constantly going to Albany with whom I would willingly trust myself, & with whom I think I could go very comfortably -- -- -- -- My dearest Papa must not withhold the expression of his wishes from any consideration of the difficulty of travelling far at this Season, for I do not fear it at all, & even if I did, I hope I could conquer trifles to gratify them. -- -- -- -- My feelings are still all interested for Mrs Morgan -- -- -- -- I must take leave of you my dear Brother, for I have scarcely time to write a few lines to Eliza -- Adieu dear Charles may Heaven bless you all -- Adieu Ever Yrs Catharine M Sedgwick I have got the letters I wrote to send by the Judge, & shall forward them by Gen'l Whiton Frances says I must scold you for your obstinate?] & unkind silence -- Indeed dear Char[les it is very wrong in you -- -- --

Saratoga Springs August 25th 1817 I am determined dear Jane that I will write you a line today, and, here to do that is no easy matter tho' the ingenuity of Man, and what is more of Woman too, is all exhausted to kill time -- The old Gentleman in resentment of the outrages committed on him seems determined to befriend nobody, not even those who have been accustomed to watch and respect every step of his incessant march -- -- We arrived here Friday Evening -- after spending a part of two days with our dear friends at Albany who we left well tho’ we found Theodore indisposed We have drank the waters faithfully, not as some drink them, as Tantalus would if he might be permitted to, often standing so long dry -- The gaiety is all at Ballstown -- The people here are from the South principally, all file off into separate & independent groupes looking at each other with a sort of defiance that might become platoons of Soldiers fighting the battles of rival states -- -- C Wilkins is here, a great relief and pleasure to me, as she is the only Lady I have met with whom I have any thing more than a speaking-acquaintance -- We met yesterday Morn’g at the spring your cousin Mr Miller. I had just time to learn from him that our friends in B ___ were well -- There are very few Eastern people here Rufus Amory, Mrs McLean, Miss Amory , Mrs Dexter and her Daughter -- One of the ‘indifferent’ Mr Parkers, all People that I don’t know, and nobody cares to know provoking, is it not dear Jane? -- Robert Watts is here and his tallents united to our own dear Bob’s are enough to wake a sleeping world -- Here is Bradish too elaborating the etiquette of the last Century which is as absurd among the nonchalant “who cares?” moderns as the brocades of our Grand-Mothers by the side of the fantastic Parisienne of the present day. If you was but here dear Jenny I think we might continue to shoot some of the folly as it flies for our own amusement and edification -- -- -- -- If I see or hear any thing worth transmitting to you I will write again -- I have half a dozen letters to write by this Morning’s Mail I can hardly yet judge of the effect of the waters -- I have had less pain for the last fortnight, and considerably less for the last two or three days -- -- You my dear Harry understand that when I write to Jane I write to you -- you have one place in my affections, and that in my very ‘heart of hearts’ -- Adieu God bless you -- YoursCMS --

New York March 12th 1814 My spirits were refreshed with your kind letter dear Eliza, soon after our return from Philadelphia -- -- In consequence of the extreme fatigue of the journey, and a cold which I caught, I have been confined to the house and chiefly to my bed until yesterday. This will excuse to you my apparent neglect in not before giving you an account of our return -- We were so continually in company while we were there that we were fairly tired out before we left there -- Just on the eve of our departure, I took care to exact your sympathy by communicating to you my horrid fears -- I was several times on the point of deciding to remain there until the travelling should be better, but that there was so little reason to hope for at this Season of the year, that I thought I might as well take my chance, for as Robert very sagely observed, the worst that could happen was breaking our necks -- -- However the roads were in fact more tedious than dangerous, & though my foolish heart was hardly out of my mouth all the way, there was more cowardice than wisdom in it -- In our mountainous regions we have no idea of the capacity of the Earth for making mud in this flat and clayey country. Robert often amused himself with imagining your misery in the like situation I am sure our fellow travellers must have often wondered who the "Little Lady” was -- However dear Eliza your sweet and welcome image always soothed me into silence and tranquility -- -- I never in any situation felt more lively emotions of confidence in the protection of Heaven, nor more animated sensations of gratitude for it -- I am convinced that if we lived more spiritually, more under the impression of a particular Providence, we should find incalculable comfort resulting from it -- that simplicity of confidence that a little Child feels in the presence of a Parent where he is assured nothing will harm him -- -- I am very anxious to hear again from your poor little Boy. I fear dear Eliza you have suffered a great deal of fatigue and anxiety for him -- He was but a delicate little plant at best, but so lovely and interesting, that I thought him worth great pains in the rearing -- -- You always have some trouble among your Children when I am away from you. The absence of my maternal care I suppose. The other day when I was sick, would you believe it dear Eliza? I was so babyish, as actually to cry because I could not see you, I thought my rheumatism would have vanished, if I could but have felt the healing touch of your little hand . -- -- -- There is in our neighborhood a most melancholy instance of the chastening Providence of God -- Col Loomis, a man of the most exquisitely tender feelings, has lost his sixth and last Child -- -- a sweet and accomplished little girl 12 years old -- She was sick about a fortnight with an inflammation on the brain, which was as usual attended with great suffering -- The Parents are both professing Christians and they have been enabled by the grace of God to exhibit a perfect submission to his holy will -- After a severe they gave her up entirely and quietly watched the ravages of the terrible disease that was to terminate a life, that had so long been the source of their sweetest joys and pleasantest expectations -- -- Ah my dear Sister there are no hopes but those that are planted on the Rock, that survive the mutability of human things -- -- A few days ago their lives were as a “morning without clouds” and now a dark night of sorrow has set upon them. But blessed be the God of consolations, He can be to them more than many Children, and can make his light to shine upon the darkness of their affliction -- -- -- -- I am not on the whole sorry that Harry’s affair with Miss is terminated, though I think with you that a little patient and manful perseverance would have won the prize. I have felt for some time, nearly indifferent about the issue, from a very comforting confidence that whatever it was, it would finally be productive of his best good -- I do Although Miss is exceedingly amiable, I do not think her quite the girl for Harry, H's habits are literary, and his pleasures intellectual, and though he certainly could not have been unhappy with Miss, still there would have been rather more mental discord, than is admissible in the full harmony of domestic life -- -- -- I have this moment received a long letter from Susan in which she says your little Boy has quite recovered. I hope I shall have many good sports with him this Summer -- Susan urges my coming to Albany very much to make her a visit -- I am not certain that I shall not, but as I do not intend to come to NYork next winter, I think I shall stay here now until I go to Stockbridge -- -- -- Charles means to go as soon as the river opens, of which however there is no immediate prospect -- as the weather continues quite cold -- Mr Watson goes to Phila’a next week -- He has been for sometime almost sick with a violent cold -- -- Frances and the Children are very well. Little Ebb is to be at home in a few weeks. I wish very much to return by the way of NHaven, but I do not know that I shall be able to effect it -- Do you wish any shopping done this spring -- If so let me have your instructions, that I may be looking out -- I have lately bought some very fine, and I think very cheap linen french -- $6 25 cents a piece 7 yds and a half in the piece 3/4 wide, $8 for the yd wide -- The linen is as fine as irish linen at $2 yd -- Would you like any of it? -- I do not yet know to what price Mrs J wishes me to go for Frances books -- I wish you would send my parasol, which hangs in the closet in my chamber to Albany immediately -- Fashionable hats are so small that it is necessary. I have been so often interrupted since I began to write that I believe for your pleasure, I might as well have not written at all. I saw Julia yesterday -- She is quite well again, and has a fine little Boy. She is very anxious to hear from Miss Fanny -- -- My love to all -- -- -- I hope to get a letter from you tomorrow, which is my gala day as it usually brings me news from you -- My dear Eliza I long to see you all, and shall ere long set my face homeward -- In the meantime forget me not Yours most affyCMSedgwick

Stockbridge June 13th 1817My dear Sister Jane, Sister in law, and in gospel; how are you? My heart greet you “yea my ‘heart of hearts’ -- -- I trust you participated in my disappointment at not seeing you again, nothing but a reason as strong as that which enforced my return would have induced me to forego meeting you and my dear Brother again -- -- I have no time now for details -- Robert will tell you all about Charles; but he cannot tell you all my sorrow at leaving Boston, Dear Jane, I think I fully realize the extent of your sacrifice, and feel the necessity, and the mercy of our doing every thing within our power to make it up to you -- -- There are some striking alleviations in the grand system of compensation -- You have left a thousand kind friends, but dear Jane could you there have gained such a Husband and Brother as you have secured at NYork -- If my dear Harry ‘serves you but half as well’ as he has me you will be highly favored among women -- And as he loves you better than ever he loved me, he will certainly be your slave for life, as Theodore predicted. Write me soon, and when you do write, let me know when we may expect to see you here -- Our friends are all impatient to see you, and feel the delightful truth that you are their Sister in very deed -- -- -- Do let me know how you like your lodgings? -- exactly how you are -- and how you feel happy, or homesick dear Jane, let me know the exact truth -- -- I have a great deal to say to you about Boston -- At present I am limited to a few moments -- -- Charles says ‘give my best love to Jane.’ She is my darling’ I think it quite as dangerous with Charles as it would be in Turkey to ‘bear a Brother near the throne’ -- -- -- I wish Harry would purchase a skein of the french paper Mrs Brush spoke of, if he likes it, and I will -- take a quarter of it -- which I should be glad to have sent by Susan, as I have none fit to write on -- my very best love to my dear Brother -- -- Ever yours dear Jane yes ever your Sister --CMS --

text: Stockbridge Novr 12th 1812 I was cruelly disappointed my dear Robert when the Southern Mail arrived without any letters for us -- But vanity is hydra-headed, and affection Phoenix-like arises from every fiery trial with new vigor. I imagined a thousand causes for the delay or miscarriage of a letter, which I had fondly hoped would have administered the consolation of sympathy for the frustration of all my plans of happiness for the winter. I beleived that my dear Brother would feel an interest nearly equal to mine in my passing the Winter in NY & I indulged a foolish expectation that you possibly might suggest some consideration in favor of my wishes which should overrule the decision of conscience -- But my towering self-consequence vanished like the mist of morning, when I read your letter to Eliza -- in which my name was not mentioned nor my existence alluded to, excepting in a little paragraph of reproach for neglect and inattention. To the charge of neglect I must plead guilty, if to have set up twice ‘till nearly two o’clock to write to you is neglect. And if the omission of no effort to contribute to your comfort and happiness in the minutest particulars is inattention, I am indeed “the most offending soul alive” -- My confident vanity required and deserved humiliation, but I didnot deserve it from you my dear Robert _____ We leave home on Monday -- notwithstanding Papa is no better. If he would give up the journey & remain satisfied and cheerful at home, I should be rejoiced -- But as he feels now, I dare not suggest my apprehensions of the effect of the journey -- The asthmatic affection is as bad as it has ever been; this enfeebles and discourages him -- I am more and more convinced that my going to Boston is almost necessary to Papa. You knowMrs Sedgwick -- Charles has not recovered his strength & as yet has not been able to ride farther than Mr Robbins -- I am perfectly able to encounter the fatigue of the journey, & disposed and determined as far as I am capable, to dissipate the gloom of the party -- It is now our turn my dear Robert to repay the kindness of this most excellent Parent -- Blessed be God for the desire to do it -- Poor Marcus died suddenly on Tuesday -- universally beloved and regretted -- The affliction of his disconsolate widow is “wondrous " & evinced in the most affecting manner -- He was attended thro’ his illness by six of the most learned of the faculty, & the last night of his life was soothed by the tender anxiety of four most vigilant -- But his disease baffled the Esculapian art, and he expired on Tuesday morning in the arms of the devoted Cady -- -- -- Our political regeneration is a subject of general exultation here -- -- It has even given Papa a temporary renovation -- -- Your Umbrella I saw put into the waggon myself (after taking some pains to find it) and into George’s care -- The Doctor says that the umbrellas were afterwards all removed to the carriage -- Mr Hicks has all your things in charge, excepting the old shirts which I have not had time to mend -- Frances knife is enclosed in the Bundle -- You shall hear from us from Springfield, if we go so far. The plan now is to turn back, in case Papa finds himself unable to endure the fatigue of riding -- I shall write a few lines to Frances -- My love to all the family, & to all my friends -- Did you ever receive a letter which I directed to be deposited in the Post-office in Hudson -- I hope my dearest Brother never to feel again, as I felt, when I read your letter yesterday -- Heaven bless you Your most affte Sister -- C M Sedgwick Charles sends his love to you all

text: New York April 3rd1812 My Dear Charles I avail myself of Mr George Morgan’s politeness (who by the way made a very friendly call on us yesterday) to anticipate this week’s mail -- of course you must not in fact fasten the sweet but illusive hope that the next post will be freighted with a letter from me -- -- . How do you support the absence of you Miss Harriet -- Beleive me I have all along thought the cautious & sly reserve you maintained on this subject very suspicious. If you had come out boldly and declared yourself heartwhole (as the Admiral says) such is my faith in your veracity that your declarations would have obtained credence -- Poor little Harriet. I think the worm must have eat up her damask cheeks long ago, indeed it must have been a jubilee to him if he found you in as good case as I left you, I should not wonder if he had died of a surfeit -- -- -- Do you know my dear Charles that the investigating philosophers of this improving age have discovered that that affection of the mind, vulgarly called Love is subject to the influence of tides, & therefore that in Seaport towns it is constantly fluctuating -- This is certainly among the impenetrable mysteries in the grand schema of nature. It is a fact & as Doctor Mason says that Man is a fool who refuses to be convinced by a fact -- All this exordium is like a flourish of trumpets, before the entrance of a Hero, to prepare you for a piece of information. You must know then that Robert has had his his heart cut into two equal parts, unfortunately by two pair of eyes belonging to beings as dissimilar as the Brobdingnagians and the Lilliputians -- The one a perfect Cleopatra in the heroic virtues, the other mild & gentle as the dews of Hermon. The other one subdues him by her potentiality, the other annihilates him by her gentleness -- -- -- I meant to have made a fine story of all this but I have been interrupted by company and must finish my letter as quick as possible -- I I absolutely long to see you all Harry has be intended to make some arrangement for coming, and going up with me -- Whether he will alter his plans I cannot say, therefore the time of my leaving here must still depend upon this contingency. Tell my dear Sister that I called on Mrs Butler yesterday. That I found her in a room about ten feet squaredownsick with a cold, and her children both sick, & as cross as little harpys without a creature to assist her except her husband -- Frances called this morning and found her out -- They have taken a house in Cortlandt Street, & the be pleasantly situated -- -- Poor Children necessity to change the liberty of the Country for situationlike this is dreadful -- You will perceive I have been in a distressing hurry -- Kiss my darling Egbert for me -- Adieu my dearest brother Ever yours Catharine M Sedgwick PS My dear Charles don’t you want a piece of linen, if you do let me know it, if Eliza has my commissions, I wish she would send them immediately. Laces of every description are a drug on the Market, & sold below their original cost -- Cheap & excellent scotch mull muslin --

Albany March 8' 1819 -- I came here my dear Robert last Monday, and find it no small item in my pleasures that I am nearer to you -- -- Your letter reached me on Friday Thursday Morning before Charles’ departure, and contained enough to make him go rejoicing st on his way, from the delightful proof that the way he had chosen is approved by you my dear Robert -- He is at the height of happiness -- with enough of certainty to make him independent of hope and yet all his future brightened with her with her glad gay coloring -- Care will come with its corrosion and disappointment with its blight, for they come to all. But Charles has an exhaustless source of contentment in his own bosom -- We have a right to expect that the blessing of his God, and the God of his Fathers will follow him -- -- If he has not what the world can give, he has what it cannot give or take away -- -- He left us Thursday Morning and proceeded to Northampton on Friday. I presume he will return to S tomorrow -- -- Eliz’ seems fully aware of the distinction which Charles' preference confers upon her -- -- Love true Love seems to me to be a notable Teacher of Humility -- -- Eliz’ poor Child seems to think her fate deserves the ‘all Hail’, but she wears her honors with all the graces of humble-mindedness -- I long to hear from you, now that you know the matter is settled, and from Harry and Jane -- Charles is exceedingly anxious to know how Harry is affected towards it -- -- -- He has had great fear of both Harry & Theodore -- -- He said he would take ‘the steps’ with Theodore if he looked dark upon him because it was folly for a Man to profess to be a Beleiver, and exercise no faith -- Harry is such a Heretic that I don’t know what he will do with him -- However I trust that Jeanie’s sentiment and his own most kind and excellent feelings will triumph over his worldly-mindedness -- I want very much to hear Jane talk about it -- Eliz’ has intended visiting N-York in the Spring -- To pay a visit to her friend Miss Woolsey -- -- Now she has Connections there, more interesting to her, her desire to go will-not probably be diminished -- By the way, since I came here, I have heard that it has been positively asserted by some knowing Gossips who know all about everything that you are engaged to Miss Woolsey!! I can’t imagine what Edward meant. My letter last letter, was such as his last to me authorized, half raillery, & half-serious -- He perhaps may have shown it to F and thus committed himself -- Henry said that the talk of Mr C’ -- attentions to Miss D. had quite subsided before he left Boston -- -- I thought it very probable the affair had issued unfortunately for E -- and I must think the young Lady stands very much in her own light -- -- Jane thinks Edward has no heart -- I do not think so -- It may not have been much in exercise, for their domestic relations have not been hallowed by the cultivation of their affections -- I believe the root of the matter is in him and it will finally produce its fruit provided it is not chilled by the solitude of a Bachelor’s life -- Thomas Warner is here -- and I beleive seriously anxious to close his concerns in the usual way -- but poor Eloise is quite sick, with a violent cold, which has attacked her lung -- Doctor James -- sayes she is doing well and will probably be out again in a few days -- -- T’s plan as I hear is to take a farm in the vicinity of your City -- Were there ever two persons less qualified for the vulgar concerns of rural economy? Eloise says she is to be the ‘Maiden all forlorn’ and ‘milk the cow with a crumpled horn’ -- -- We are daily hoping to hear the fate of Doctor Osborne -- Poor Charlotte Caldwell has fallen a victim to the Consumption She died Saturday night -- -- We are told that after suffering the most horrible conflict -- she became resigned and happy -- -- The transition from her gay and trifling life to the sublime realities of Death and the Judgment to come has is appalling -- -- and nothing but the strength that is perfected in weakness, could sustain the soul -- -- I have been delightfully interrupted by your letter by Dr James -- You feel just as I thought you would -- -- and I am delighted perfectly delighted that Harry and Jane join in the warm and full expression of felicitation -- Charles will now be perfectly satisfied -- He loves all his family so much that he could not have been happy if they were not -- -- Charles will write Mrs Brush -- It will be the best way of breaking the fall I find she anticipates it from her last letter to me -- and speaks of it in a manner that does credit to her understanding, & great honor to her heart -- Susan, Mrs Symmes and all send Love -- Mine to all -- Beleive me dearest Brother Ever yoursCMS -- Will not Sue Jeanie and Eliz’ make a superb triumvirate? If you do not fill it up a partie quarrée , in a way to do you honor, I shall share the destiny of Sir S Romilly -- -- I cannot find out that there is any decision about the Sugar or Coffee I have asked Susan -- but she says her Husband has not decided

New York Nov'r 22'nd1808 We received your letter my dear Papa from Salem, yesterday Morning -- it is incomprehensible to us, that you should not have received any of Frances’s letters -- She has written three times, since you have been in Boston -- You say nothing of my poor representative, from which I presume you have received it. I confess its insignificance rendered it unworthy of an acknowledgement, but you know my dear Papa, there is a kind of parental pride in Authorship, which is perhaps too easily wounded and if I were ingenuously to tell you all, I should be compelled to confess that your addressing your letters exclusively to my elder Sister, has excited a little of that jealousy; which is a portion of my inheritance from the paternal estate I presume you will have heard long before this letter reaches Boston, of Theodore’s and Susan’s arrival in this City -- Susan is already almost recovered, by the most simple remedy in the world, the presence of her grand restorative, who may well boast with in relation to her, to be as universal a cure, as the most wonder working patent Medicine -- They are to be joined in holy wedlock on monday evening next, at Brockholst Livingston’s, in as private a manner, as propriety will admit of -- Her Aunts, and one or two very dear friends, Mr Watson, our dear Charles provided he arrives in season, Frances and myself are to compose the nuptial train -- Theodore has obtained a triumph similar to yours, and won a promise from poor Susan, that she will sacrifice her liberty of conscience, and be married in a most anti-dogmified,, plebian style, by a Presbyterian Clergyman, -- They will leave New York on the Wedn’y following, in Captain Bunker’s packet and will probably arrive at our dear home a fortnight before you -- -- You seem to have had some uneasiness excited by the secrecy of a late letter, written to me. You will I am sure be gratified to hear, that it was a motive of generosity towards me, that induced the kind writer of it, the refuse you the perusal of it -- I empower you my dear Papa to request her to show you the last letter I wrote her on the subject, if it is still in being that, together with a few words of explanation, or confession, (whichever you please to term it) will acquaint you with an affair about which, I should never have had any reserve towards you, had I not feared that it would have diminished that confidence, which you have so bountifully reposed in me -- -- -- -- -- Last Spring while I was in Boston, Miss Russell told she thought MrsJ unfriendly to her, she it from several sources, mentioning Mrs Derby, , Jay and I beleive James Savage. I was indignant at MrsJ’s continued & unparalleled abuse of a friend, who I thought so underserving of it -- I confirmed her suspicions, and moreover specified some of the Articles of defamation, though it was but "a sand on the sea shore” compared to the whole number -- I know not what motives you will ascribe to this conduct -- Perhaps you will think it was the common, tale-bearing, tattling propensity of a silly girl -- Permit me to say my dear Father I was not motivated by a feeling so dishonorable to me -- On a calm review of it, I have censured myself for it because I was indebted to Mrs -- for much kindness and because the communication, could subserve no good end but never shall I think the impulse that led me to it execrable -- Do my dear Papa, relieve me, by your opinion on the subject, and let it be as lenient as possible -- -- The family all unite with me in the kindest remembrance to you, and yours -- With the most ardent prayers for your health and happiness beleive me Your affy Catharine M Sedgwick

Boston Jan'y 22nd1813 Friday night I wrote last night to Frances my dear Brother imparting our joy and hopes -- Tonight I must darken it all by the intelligence that our Parent again appears to be declining -- These alternations of hope and despondency cannot be endured My dear Brother we must all prepare our minds for that issue so dreadful to us, but so joyful as I humbly trust to our dear Father -- From Sister’s letter which shewe received today I think she must be on her way here -- . I hope not, for I think she couldnot endure the fatigue of such a journey -- -- Still I wouldnot dissuade her from attempting it, if I thought she would be consoled by seeing Papa -- but oh my Brother it is agonizing to watch the last struggles of nature -- May our Gracious Father have us all in his holy keeping -- Yours affy CMS Henry D & Eliza arrived today Papa recognized Eliza --

text: New York March 14th1812 If I cheat you of one moment of weariness my dear Papa, I shall attain more than I dare promise myself -- I must own myself indebted to your partiality for the pleasure my letters give you in the best of times, but now I am particularly stupid from the conjoined influence of a cold and headache. I had a most excellent letter from Charles, and another from Eliza by the last mail -- They both give us favorable accounts of your recovery -- I hope you will on no account leave home ‘till you are perfectly restored. The weather at this Season of the year is always variable and this spring seems to be particularly unhealthy I know I need not employ any arguments to convince you that your own fireside is more favorable to you than the fatigue and bustle of travelling and business could be. How thankful ought we all to be my dear Father that you have a Son of such devoted affection as Charles. He seems to me to be a perfect model of filial virtue -- From his actions, his conversation, and his letters, you discern his prevailing desire to be, to add to your enjoyment -- I could expatiate on this very dear subject for half a day, but I could not throw any light on those qualities that you see in their full blaze of excellence every day -- Our friend Rodman has returned from Paris, a good deal contaminated I am afraid with french principles -- A complete Frenchman in politicks -- He tells an anecdote which as far as our Country is concerned in the respectability of Mr Barlow as its Representative, is of some consequence -- It seems that the famous Miss Helen Maria Williams had gone over to France under the protection of Mr Stone & his Wife -- After the party had been on the Continent for some little time, Mr Stone preferring Miss Williams to his wife, turned the latter out of doors, and committed the dignity and honor of his household into the keeping of Miss W -- Mrs Stone who had brought her husband the fortune on which he is rioting with Miss W, is now begging her bread in Paris -- And last and worst of all, Mr & Mrs Barlow tho’ they had previously been in habits of intimacy with Mrs Stone, call on Miss Williams and receive her at their home. Is not this my dear Papa a fine exhibition of the rigor and simplicity of republican morality? What a complete annihilation of every thing like moral sentiment there must be in France -- You will hear in Boston the story of poor Derby’s discomfiture at Washington -- -- -- I wish you would tell Mrs Sedgwick that we will send the Bismith to Boston We have had no opportunity to send it to Stockbridge -- The children all desire that they may be represented to their Grandpapa in the most amiable light -- The little Gov’ is quite unwell -- He is the most charming child I ever saw -- If my dear Eliza should see this last paragraph, tell her, her’s are always excepted -- -- -- I hope that Catharine Pearse will forgive my long silence in consideration of a long letter that I am to write her -- Remember us all to Mrs Sedgwick, Catharine, Charles &c -- My dear Papa do let us see some evidence in black and white of your recovery -- May the Father of all mercies long very long preserve your health -- the best of blessings to us -- Ever yours CMS

text: Stockbridge Feby 3rd1813 I need not tell you my dear Brother that I never so much longed to see you, to mingle my sorrow with your sorrow, and my joy with your joy -- to be assured dear Theodore of your increased affection, of your protecting kindness -- -- I feel for all my Brothers new sensations of love and dependence -- -- Grief gives new impetuosity to the current of our affections The bonds of our that unite us are sanctified by the removal of our Parents and I feel a sweet assurance my dear Theodore, that no sound of discord will ever disturb the harmony that has been cultivated and blessed by our Father I feel an anxiety that I cannot conquer for my dear Sister I should go immediately to Albany if I didnot beleive her to be much better Eliza wishes me to tell you that if she can be of any service or comfort to our dear Susan she will go up immediately & stay as long as she can be spared -- If she cannot be of some benefit, she had rather defer going, as it is inconvenient for her to leave home at present -- If she goes my society and services would be superfluous and while Harry remains at home, it is extremely inconvenient for me to leave here -- Do let us know by the return of the stage exactly how Susan is, and if you desire it we will certainly one of us come up -- Dear Susan -- dearer now than ever May God in his infinite mercy my beloved Brother long spare you the dreadful stroke of separation -- -- Yours most affy CMS

Stockbridge June 29th 1817 Sunday Eveg -- I have just exchanged the good-night kiss with Eloise and Frances, and looked into your vacant room as I passed it dear Charles, breathing a sigh that went all the way to Saratoga -- Your room has a sepulchre look, indeed the whole house without you is not much better, I go all about it, saying like the poor old Mariner “it is not here” “it is not there” I would give half my little fortune to hear how you are tonight -- My hopes are like the rose buds in our garden, the genial the sun yesterday warmed them into life and almost into expansion. But today the cold Easterly blasts have shrunk and chilled them almost to extinction -- God be praised you are his Child my beloved Brother, and he doth not willingly grieve or afflict his children _____ Eloise arrived most opportunely -- She is in delightful spirits, and the excitement of her society counteracts in some degree, the depression of our solicitude -- She arrived at Hoag’s at 6 O’clock with Doctor Brown who she confesses rivals the English Nobleman in “de grande talens pour le silence” -- She says he once remarked “that was a high hill” and once that “that was a deep gutter” -- He very kindly offered to stay at Hoag’s for her, but she advised him to trot on with his tired horse and she came in the next morning in the stage -- in company with George Morgan, who she found civil and agreeable -- -- I hope we shall be able to retain her “till your return, but she expects to go this week -- Nothing has occured since your departure excepting the long expected arrival of little Mr Farnum and my tea and watch! (a fine climax) -- Lincoln is going on with his operation and I infer from the slowness of his progress that like other geniuses he works for fame and posterity -- ‘Tho all honor is raised, and to my eye is so beautiful that it might pass for a grecian temple, or a chinese pagoda, or a Turkish minaret, or any thing classic or foreign – Mr Rice pays a matin and vesper visit to the vaches and cochins not forgetting the little Heifer, who is so near maternal honors, that I shall not ransack my memory for any but her english name -- -- I have not yet heard from Mary D, but I hope she will be in this week -- One thing my dear Charles I charge you to let me know the whole truth concerning yourself -- I had heard of your great suffering at Nassau, and the magnanimity of your letter rather pained me, because it proved that you would conceal the worst from me -- I should like a visit to Saratoga, particularly with such a pretext as your sickness would furnish me, therefore I beseech you to withhold nothing of all your pains & penalties -- -- We were all rejoiced to hear of the Colonel’s improvement -- I hope in mercy he will return to us without any momento of Adam’s transgression -- -- If the Sun shines tomorrow, and there is a quadruped to be hired, begged or borrowed in the village, we (the trio E, F, and myself) are going on a harem-scarem expedition, to glide a la Cherubina over the goodly lands “that floweth &c to spy out all the bye-places where the youthful Hero went out to meditate at even-tide -- -- -- We have had our usual Sunday Evening Coterie, and all the members of our Church, and State are well -- -- Cynthia and I have worked like Heroines, and got the house in readiness to give you a clean and smiling welcome -- I wish you would get me on your return cwt of white havanna sugar, provided it is so much cheaper than lumps as to make it an object to use it instead of that -- At any rate you had better get it for I shall want a good deal in in the course of the Season for various purposes, for which it is as good as lump and better than brown -- If you cannot conveniently bring it, Do not fail to bring 3 or 4 lbs which I want imm’y -- I have prated away my dear Charles on the presumption that you will have time to throw away at Saratoga -- -- Monday morning -- I wrote last evening on this blotting paper ‘till my eye was dim. It has ceased to rain, and a westerly wind promises us again a fair Heaven -- -- -- The water is high, but not quite round the Island -- Robt doesnot intend coming on before August -- Jane is gratified with her reception at New York -- She has been received with great hospitality -- I am now going into the Garden to sow the seeds you sent to me -- The pepper graft has already forced its tiny leaves thro’ the Earth -- I do not wonder the Persians worshipped the Sun -- all vegetable nature pays to it long involuntary adoration -- -- I have dreamt of you all night my beloved Brother and waked this morning groaning “oh dear Charles” -- Still I am determined that all my sad fancies shall be ‘omens for good.’ My dear Brother I pray you to be cautious -- . I hope not be disappointed in hearing from you by every mail that arrives ‘till I see you either here or at Saratoga We shall go to Canaan tomorrow but not till after the stage arrives -- Frances and Eloise send to you their love and blessings -- -- We talk of you dear Charles as often as the best disciple of ‘the Prophet’ says his prayers, and think of you as a Christian prays “without ceasing” I have sent to Mrs Brown to know how they all are -- She begs me to give her best love to her Husband -- do tell him they are all quite well and that Wm arrived safely Saturday Morning -- Give my best regards to the Col -- -- All well at the Doctor’s -- God bless you dearest Charles and return you in amended health to your us -- Your's everCMS --

Albany Sunday Evening You will not be sorry my dear Frances to hear that your little sea faring girl arrived here safely yesterday morning -- She broke my slumbers about seven o’clock and patiently waited for three or four minutes ‘till I recovered sufficient consciousness to give her an affectionate recognition -- -- Her pale cheek is proof enough that she wants country air and liberty -- Papa is extremely disappointed that Eben did not come with her -- -- -- We have been detained here two days longer than we expected from Papa’s inability to ride in damp weather -- -- His asthmatic affection has been much more troublesome lately, which we impute to the continued dampness of the atmosphere. This disorder has debilitated him very much & dispirited him a good deal He intended to have written to you and Mr Watson today, but has not felt quite strong enough to attempt it -- -- -- -- Susan has now determined to wait postpone going to NYork until Mr B’s return, provided the rumor of the adjournment of Congress proves true. This place tho’ distant from immediate danger is very much affected by the disastrous state of our affairs -- Every mind is overshadowed with gloom -- What have we to do my dear Frances, but to seek that favor which can ever smile upon us thro’ the thick clouds of calamity that envellope our Country. How surpassing all conception is the blessedness of that faith which can make us firm and tranquil and confident, when all around us speak the language of despondence, and every circumstance threatens us with suffering “I know that my Redeemer liveth” was the language of a Christian when every other consolation was wrested from him, may this sentiment my dear Frances encourage and animate our faltering spirits -- who that has ever experienced its blessed influence would give it up, for all the Kingdoms of this world, and the glory of them -- -- -- We go tomorrow, if nothing unforeseen takes place -- Papa is a good deal better this week evening -- Whenever you think best to come to S my dearest Frances, my arms and heart will be open to receive you. I cannot but feel a great deal of distressing anxiety for you in your present situation, and I beseech you not to remain in NY a moment after there is any risque in being there -- -- I will do every thing in my power for my two dear little charges, & with the blessing of Heaven on my efforts I hope I shall perform my duty -- My best love to Mr Watson. I intend writing him by the next regular Mail -- If you can purchase a handsome dark canton crape not exceeding $ I wish you would. I had rather not have not have more than eight yds -- I should like a dark lead color or brown -- You may keep it ‘till you come up, as I shall not want it for a long time but it is now necessary to be provident -- If you havenot already bought the gloves I requested, I wish you would not get them at all -- God bless you my dear Sister Ever yours CMS
