text: Boston Jan'y 5th 1813 A thousand thanks to you my dear Sister for devoting so much time to us, amidst your various cares, and perplexities -- To my dear Brother,too I am very much indebted for his most excellent and christian letter -- I have not been able to write you as I have wished -- various occupations and frequent interruptions, have distracted my attention -- At all times it has been a sourcesubject of gratitude that I had such a brother, and such a Sister, and that the christian bond that unites us, should annihilate the distance that separates us -- -- God grant that I may improve the dispensations of his Providence as you have done, that his chastening and his mercies may increase my love and devotion -- My dear Sister, our fears have been calmed by the favorable appearance that our Father’sdisorder put on, but for a few days past he has not gained, and, for two days I think he has lost ground -- -- -- He has been uniformly silent as to the his own feelings, and apprehensions till yesterday -- Yesterday Mrs S walked out for the first time -- and while she was gone I was alone with him -- -- He began said to me (without my introducing the subject) that he had for many years been extremely desirous to make a public profession of religion, (here he was so much agitated as to be obliged to stop for some time) He had been deterred from very unworthy motives that he had feard giving pain to Doctor West and many good people in Stockbridge by joining any other than their Church, and he couldnot bringing his feelings to joining that. He was so much overcome, that I made every effort to sustain and assure him -- I told him that Mr Channing had been desirous to see him He said that if he understood Mr Channing’s belief, it agreed with his better than any other Clergyman’s in Boston, and should it please God to restore to him sufficient health, it should be his first act to devote himself to him -- -- I suggested that should he wish it, Mr C would administer the sacrament to him here -- “ Not at present my love said he, for if it should please God I wish to do it in the face of the world” -- My dear Frances, I know you will be overwhelmed with gratitude, that we have so much to console us in any event -- How shall we evince our sense of the tender mercies of our God, and above all this last surpassing kindness -- -- This is but another instance of the importance of embracing the first opportunity of joining ourselves to the visible Church assure my dear Brother, that so deeply am I impressed with it, that no difficulties, no sacrifices of feeling will deter me from making every effort to possess such privileges, as I am indeed unworthy of -- Our dear Brothers are all kind and attentive, and our Father is now in some measure reaping the reward of his unexampled parental tenderness -- -- -- Robert cannot decide at present when he shall return -- -- Papa says “do my dear give my love to your Sister and Eben” -- -- I left the half handkerchief at home in Eliza’s care and desired her to send it to you or get it worked there, as you preferred -- -- Do you mean to have a lace or muslin vandyke? -- -- I am anxious to hear from your poor Children, and am afraid you will be exhausted with fatigue and anxiety _____ Continue to write my dearest Sister when you can, for your letters edify and delight me -- Mrs S and the boys join in love to you all -- May God have you in his holy keeping -- Ever yours aff'y C M S

Stockbridge October 28' I have deserved my dear Jane that you should before this have wiped out all trivial fond records of me, and yet I feel very sure that notwithstanding my good-for-nothingness, you have not abated one whit of your good-will -- The fact is that my Correspondents collectively remind me of the plagues of Egypt, tho individually they are my very best blessings -- I have this moment dispatched a letter to Eloise, the first I have written to her for many weeks, notwithstanding the stimulus of two delightful letters from her -- -- My dear Jenny! I long to see you -- to see the kind beaming of your tender-eye, and to hear the sweet music of your voice. . I cannot express to you how much I forego of my personal gratification by giving up seeing you and my beloved Brothers this Fall; and postponing it thro’ this long, and as it now seems interminable Winter -- There are many objections; and in the first place, (which seems indeed to preclude the necessity of any other reason,) I have not yet heard from Mrs Banyer. However I am sure I shall shortly; for I should as soon doubt the faith of an Abdiel, as a Jay -- The Season is already too far advanced to admit of comfortable travelling However that I would not mind; but I could not stay more than three weeks < -- without running some risk from the Ice -- So short a time would only provoke my appetite, without at all satisfying it -- Added to all this I have various domestic embarrassments, and grievances, that would make no figure on paper, tho’ they oppose a phalanx that might daunt a stouter heart than mine -- I think my dear Jane that our gloomy forebodings in relation to your situation in NY -- have been most delightfully dispelled -- You seem to have attracted around you a Circle of Worthies that would do no disgrace to your native soil -- I should like very much to see Margaret invested with her bridal honors; tho she could hardly be more interesting to me, than she was independent of any external circumstance, or accidental brightness -- -- -- I wish you would tell Harry that his and my friend Mrs Morgan leaves here this week for England, via New York -- She goes there to pass the Winter! -- and returns in the Spring with her Daughter -- Mr Ashburner remains here -- I think we shall probably derive a considerable pleasure from his Society -- He is intelligent & very Gentlemanly -- A most extraordinary figure He is an East-Indian by birth; and his complexion has the sallowness peculiar to that climate -- His hair tho’ he does-not appear to be more than 50, is perfectly white, “and streams like a Meteor to the troubled air” His eye is black and piercing his nose and mouth prominent and bold -- Such a description must give a very imperfect idea of a face so singularly expressive as Mr A’s -- I have been interrupted by a long visit from Mr Woodbridge, and a Pittsfield Military Beau -- By the way, I beleive W-ge is engaged to a Miss Childs of Pittsfield We are all well in our little Circle -- Men and women, man servants and maid-servants and Cattle, all growing fat upon the abundant products of the year -- My dear Jane I should not write on such shabby paper, but I can get no other -- I have written to Albany and NYork in vain for some -- -- I wish you would tell Brother Robert that I received his kind letter on Saturday and I hope he will be satisfied with the answer to it that this letter contains -- Madame la Veuve -- Est-elle revenue? -- God bless thee dear Sister Yours everCMS --

Stockbridge August 5th 1813 You must know dear Robert that I have grown very methodical in the arrangement of my time. This morning I had allotted to you at least such a portion of it as would enable me to write you a letter, and in some measure to reward you for your last excellent and kind favor -- But some calls of duty, and some of civility have consumed my time, and some melancholy news has so completely saddened my mind that I am unfitted for exertion -- Gracious indeed is the assurance that our Heavenly Father chastiseth whom he loveth & blessed & sustaining the proof He vouchsafed to us in the Person of his well-beloved Son in acquainting Him with sorrow, and making him familiar with grief -- -- Our poor afflicted Uncle Doctor is fast making up the measure of his sufferings, drinking the last dregs of his bitter cup -- -- Emily is visited with the same calamity that has overwhelmed her Sisters. Her hopes for this world cut off for-ever -- Blessed be God dear Robert this world passeth away as a shadow -- There is a Heavenly rest for the disembodied soul where mortality cannot invade us -- -- -- -- Emily has been ever since the great excitement of her mind last winter, dreadfully afflicted with pains in her head -- She had however got a good deal better, when Uncle (about six weeks since, carried her to Middlebury in the expectation of establishing her health -- Last night he was sent for to Pittsfield, where she has arrived, and is today to be brought home -- -- I must go there, and endeavor to sustain them, with the little fortitude I have -- God be merciful to them _____ I received Frances letter today by Doctor Williams, and am rejoiced to hear that the time of her coming is finally settled -- Susan wishes Frances to purchase for her one of Smith’s wash-Balls -- Frances says dear Robert that you are not well -- Let me intreat you not to remain in N York but to come to the care of a Sister who loves you with all the tenderness her heart is capable of -- -- The weather is intensely hot even here, and I shall feel very anxious for you Every day convinces me that there are few enjoyments whose memorial will last beyond this world but surely among those is that which we have in the society of one another -- Dearest Brother, do come to us to our healthy, peaceful, and affectionate home -- I have just heard from Uncle’s, Emily has got home, and is much more calm -- Uncle as composed as if he was removed to the presence of his God, & had seen that all these things had worked together for good to him -- -- -- I went to Lebanon yesterday in the hope of seeing Miss B -- but she has not yet arrived there -- -- -- I think I look forward with more solicitude to your finding a worthy yoke-fellow than to my own success -- -- A thousand thanks to you dear Robert for your kind proposition relative to the Western jaunt -- I feel no right to take the place either of Harry or yourself -- When do you go? _____ We are all well -- My best love to my Brother and Sister -- Ever yours dear Robert CMS

N York Feb 4th 1802 Although My Dear Mama I have written once this week I cannot deny myself the pleasure of writing you again I find Mama through your influence )as I suppose) I have at length received a couple of letters I find they had all quite forgotten me except you I knew if you could you would have written me you would My Dear Mama and have informed me how you all were at home Sister has received letters from some one of the family every week and it gives me a great deal of pleasure to read them but Mama I fear I am selfish it is so pleasant to receive letter from persons you love as affectionately as I do the inhabitants of our house I think I am very very much to blame for not having answered Abbys excellent letter but I will write her soon I am very much obliged to Aunt Dwight for the postscript she put in Roberts letter I intended to have written her a letter upon the other side of the sheed but Frances wants to write Do Mama give my love to Robert and Harry tell the I meant to have written them but Mr Watson say that I must not send two letters by one mail Your Dutiful and affectionate Daughter Catharine M S

Albany Feb'y 15th 1818My dear Sister -- And I wish those words were magic to bring me -- into your presence and that of the dear little beings that surround you -- My dear Frances since I came away I have felt almost the yearning of a Mother’s heart towards them -- -- Their goodness and their love has endeared them inexpressibly to me, I feel as if I had an inalienable property in them -- and I beleive I have -- I know I am indebted to you for a great deal of their affection, and I know another thing that I do-not deserve it -- in the degree their tender hearts have accorded it -- -- My beloved Sister -- may we never love one another less than we dow now -- and oh on my part, may that love be productive of more and better fruit! -- I was very glad you didnot go to Blandford last week -- I think you would have been laid up at our friend Mr Keep’s with the erisipolis , and Charles with the Rheumatism -- I hope you will give me a history of your excursion, and of Theodore’s situation there -- -- Monday morning -- . I am inclined to think that you and Charles spent Sunday at Brentford -- and have this charming day for your return. -- -- The weather has been so cold since I have been here, that I have hardly stirred out of the house excepting on Sunday. -- The You “set so loosely to the world” that its most attractive hues, do not attract your eye, and the world of Albany has hardly variety or novelty enough to interest a novice -- -- -- It would be impossible unless I was suffering under the pressure of severe calamity not to be happy with our dear Brother and Sister. It would be as bad a sign as to ‘hate bread & the laugh of a Child’ -- -- but beyond this threshold there is very little to stimulate or gratify curiosity, and very few sources of rational every-day enjoyment -- -- Verplank is here, and as Anna Bridgen says, he looks as if he had never felt a pang -- But after you get over the first mournful thoughts of his lovely wife, and her suffering and death, which the thought of him awakens, you cannot fail to be entertained by him -- He has seen most things and persons about which that we are curious about. I could not but compare him to our friend Warner when he returned from the same tour and think how inferior are his descriptions, to those of Warner -- his mind illustrated every Subject, his sensibility enriched it and the bright beams of his imagination fell upon it, lighting it with such glories as the Sun kindled in the Heavens, a few Sundays ago -- -- -- After all this these mere matter of fact people, tho’ they may be very useful profitable animals, are as much inferior to such a man as Warner in their power to interest and delight impractical as he may be, as a dull useful tradesman is to a valiant magnanimous chivalrous chieftain, or a wild Bard with a fine frenzy rolling eye . Verplank met Doctor Mason in France and in England. he says he looks vastly better than he did abroad -- He says he was proud to call him his Countryman -- He met him at a society for the relief of for Chimney-sweepers. as The Doctor made a beautiful little speech on the occasion in which he compared British charity to the proboscis of the Elephant which with equal ease, could root up the oak, and pick up a cambric needle -- -- But to come home to our own matters. -- The other day when I got your little letter I gave Bob your message -- “Well said Maria I think Aunt Frances might have said something of me too” -- Your Aunt said had time to write but a short letter, “ah, but she found time to speak of Bob -- and afterwards she was enumerating the Aunts she loved best -- Theodore reproached her with not naming you -- ah says she that letter I can’t forget that letter, but, said Theodore, Aunt Frances has sore eyes’ ‘Sore eyes, sore eyes, says Maria, I have heard about those eyes a million of times, but she can always see to write a great deal about you” -- -- -- She is one of the smartest little creatures I ever saw -- -- -- I intended and still intend to write to my dear Kate by the Doctor, if I should be prevented I will write her very soon -- My best love to her, and to Fanny and Bob -- I meant before I came away to have brought the rug out of my room, and placed it before the stove -- to save the Carpet I wish you would do it -- I shall send the chocolate, and some venison, if I can obtain it, & the Doctor will carry it -- If there are any little matters you want in the family from time to time you must let me know it -- Do let me know how you get along with the Domestics I am afraid you will have more plague than enough -- -- I hope Charles will come up next week and pass a day or two with us _____ Adieu my dearest Frances -- Yours ever truly --CMS _____ I bought “my Grandmother” for little Fan as a return for the box she gave me, but on looking at it -- I find it more suitable for Kate -- accordingly I have put my her name in it -- I have bought a Crimper for you as you may be put to inconvenience from mine, which I brought away with me -- -- I couldnot find any leather Garters -- I therefore return the silk ones -- and hold -- myself bound to get you a pair of leather whenever I find them -- I hope you have-not been put to inconvenience, from the want of the cotton, which I carelessly brought away -- I have begged a Portfolio containing a sketch of Sir James Mc Intosh -- wh because I thought it might be gratifying to Mr Ashburner to see what the Americans say of his friend I wish you would give it to him with my compliments -- I wrote this letter before Theodore came -- I thank you for your's my dear Sister -- -- -- My love to the Children -- -- --

Stockbridge July 23rd 1812 My dear Robert, Thus my pen almost instinctively commences, & thus does my heart dictate to one who I love to the utmost extent of my capacity, tho’ I donot I am sure I do not beyond his merits -- As you must know how hard it is to wrest from me my confidence in my own opinion, I wish to preclude any further effort on your part, by assuring you ‘once for all, that on the subject of your deserts, it has obtained such complete dominion over my heart that no human power can affect it -- -- This is not girlish rant, nor thoughtless profession; I have passed the age of these follies, & my dear Robert has not yet to learn that a Brother is not often the unfortunate subject of romantic sallies -- No, that affection which I profess binds my soul to yours, and directs its most ardent aspirations to an immortal union, thro’ the mercy of Christ -- -- This is the day appointed for our fasting humiliation and prayer -- It becomes us while we humble ourselves under the chastising hand of the Governor of the World, to acknowledge his parental mercy in giving to our State a Magistrate, whose ‘walk is in all godliness’, who honoreth his Creator and therefore we may hope will have “honor and majesty put upon him” -- . The meeting today was very generally attended by the democratic party, some of them however, even members of the Church in defiance of decency have misused their common occupations, because they couldnot in conscience, they couldnot without hypocrisy attend a meeting which was in pursuance of such a proclamation as Govr Strong’s -- I wish there was sufficient efficiency in the Authority of our Church to tear the vizor from such depravity as this -- -- We have heard tonight that NYork is blockaded, but as rumor has all her tongues in operation just now, we know not what to believe -- What do you think of our Cradle of Liberty? If the cry we hear from it, is the cry of infancy, what will the voice of the Man be. Very like in its sound probably to the “shrill fife, and spirit stirring drum” -- For my part, tho a ‘weak woman’ I am heroine enough to rejoice that our banner still waves in freedom, and those who hear it, are not yet grovelling in fearful submission -- -- But to descend from the nation to the dear founder of our family dynasty, I am happy to inform you that he is better -- His complaints are not however entirely removed I should have written to Sister today in reply to her very kind letter by the way of Albany, but Papa preoccupied the ground -- -- And at this time particularly, I know she will prefer a letter line from Papa, to folios from me – I have not yet answered my sweet friend C Wilkins letter simply because, I have a suspicion that she is not fond of writing -- She ought to be, for she writes in a style almost as winning as her own lovely face -- There is a report current in these parts that you are on the eve of marrying with a Miss Wilkins . -- I presume the report came from head quarters, tho’ I am ignorant of its source -- Jarvis married on Monday morning, and went immediately to Utica on visit to Mrs Lee -- Catharine Russell says as she has no communication to make from world of spirits, where she presumes from your silence that you think she is gone, she cannot possibly write to you -- I think my dear Robert considering you are ‘next best’ you are in duty bound to write -- -- -- -- C has no affectation, and her as mind ‘rose elastic from the tread’ of affliction, she is now in a very comfortable state of spirit -- Why does Frances defer coming up? With the blessing of Heaven we shall all meet again in August -- I wish you would give me a proper direction to Susan -- I shall write as soon as I get it -- -- Remember me aff’y all my friends -- Beleive me dear Brother yours most sincerely CMS -- Laura's love

text: N NewYork 13 12th December 1801 My Dear Papa I received your kind letter on tuesday last. I cannot express to you how much pleasure it gave me. I am very sorry papa that Mr Williams has forsaken you. I think tis very likely he has found some sweet girl that attracts his attention So perhaps tis not too late for him to get him a wife yet. Tell him for me, if you please, that I will give up all my right to him but that he is very inconstant. I have been to the play but once since I have been here. Macbeth was played then. I was not as much pleased with the play as I expected to be; the afterpiece was Rosina . It was a very pretty thing, and was performed very well. Tomorrow night we go to see Abbellino or the Great Bandit and the Roma. Sister thinks I had better learn french, and wants to know yours and Mama’s opinion. Your Dutiful Daughter Catharine M Sedgwick

Stockbridge Feby 15th1813 We have not yet my dear Frances heard a word from you since we parted -- I hope that our expectations will be satisfied by tomorrow’s Mail as I am particularly anxious to hear from your poor little Girl -- Such a bereavement as we have suffered dear Sister gives the alarm to all our affections, and compels us to feel the mutability of every possession -- Every day’s experience teaches me better what we have lost, and enables me I hope in some degree to improve this rebuke of our Heavenly Father -- -- Still when I review the few last years, I forget the bitterness that has been infused into our cup of joy, the of our cares, and we seem to have closed a day of happiness whose brightness was never shaded by a single cloud, or sullied with a single spot -- But this is the temporary illusion of imagination for on my memory are the records of some sorrows & many disappointments -- -- -- -- -- -- We have been greatly distinguished; for temporal mercies we owe all the gratitude that our natures are capable of. And how much more my dear Sister do we owe for that love which makes even our afflictions a blessing to us, which takes the poison from the arrow that wounds us, and heals the wound it inflicts; which when it deprives us of the light that has brightened our Path in this world, pours upon the eye of faith the glorious light of immortality -- -- How entire and how ardent should bedevotion to him, who by by his sufferings purchased such consolations to sustain us -- Who could have assured our sinking spirits, or spoken peace to our troubled hearts, in our hour of trial, if our faith had not pointed to the resurrection and the life -- I had written thus far dear Sister when I was interrupted by the arrival of Harry and Theodore from Albany. I am now obliged to close my letter while my heart is full -- -- I received by this mail letters from Robert & Eloise -- I intend answering them by the Friday’s mail, but I am so much occupied in preparations for Harry’s departure that I am not certain I shall be able to accomplish it -- Eliza is yet in Albany -- Susan remains very feeble -- My dear Frances I cannot close my letter without telling you how deeply your tenderness to me in our affliction affected May you be blessed for it my Sister -- And your Husband too -- But I can only requite him with a Sister’s love -- -- -- -- Charles goes to Albany tomorrow -- Kiss the children for me especially dear little Bob -- My love to my dear Brothers and Sister Eloise -- -- -- EverYours CMS -- Charles love -- also, Mrs S -- --

My dear little Robert -- I was very much grieved to hear that you was ‘pretty sick’, but I hope that you are quite well again and very happy My dear Boy we do indeed all want very much to see you, and your Brothers, and little dimpled Fanny, -- Tell Theodore and Eben, that I say they are both scamps, for not writing to me -- I shall certainly cut them off with a shilling to buy a halter -- -- -- As to you my darling I have as pretty a picture of you in my heart as ever you saw, -- -- Maria thanks you for her letter -- It made her eyes sparkle like a diamond, the most brilliant stone in the world you know -- -- Theodore has begun to go to school -- His Mama is just giving him a geography lesson and he answers so queerly that he makes us all laugh -- -- I am in a great hurry, so goodbye my darling -- Your most affectionateAunt Catharine --

Stockbridge Nov' 15' 1818 -- Sunday -- I think my dearest Robert it will be no profane appropriation of a part of this holy day to devote it to you -- particularly as I shall have no other time to acknowledge the receipt of your last kind letter -- -- -- You used to say “I flatter myself there is some religion in the affections” --, and I beleive that He who said ‘the Sabbath was made from for man" would not reject from it, the cultivation of those immortal affections that ennoble his Being, and preserve in him some features of the Image, in which he was originally made of that God who is Love _____ I was shocked for a moment by the conclusion of your last letter, and I havenot cast my eye on it since, without a superstitious shudder. I beg you will be more careful in future It was thus ‘Farewell forever’ _____ If it was not that this enlightened, philosophic age precludes those presentiments that were ingenious tormentors of during their reign of terror, I certainly should have made myself very miserable -- -- I was rejoiced to notice a sober reality in your Postscript -- -- I have no fears that you will remain a Bachelor -- And I had no ambition for an alliance with Miss D. on any other grounds than that of a strong mutual affection -- You must now wait dear Robert ‘till some angel shall trouble the waters --. Your heart must be like the fabled harp that could only be waked to music by the one touch -- If worst comes to worst dearest Robert you and I will comfort one another’s old age -- That worst would be to me like that state where there is no marrying nor giving in marriage in more respects than one _____ I begged Frances when she went to Albany to ascertain from S what would be her wish respecting my going there if she was sure of a final disappointment of her wishes -- Frances has not written me a word on the subject -- But as Susan has never even hinted at that motive for my going to A -- and as even she must see think there is not the slightest probability of the event she desires, I think she would-not rest it on that ground -- Susan’s intreaties ought my dear Robert, to influence me -- From my childhood, she has been the tenderest and most devoted friend and Sister to me -- I could-not find it in my heart to do any thing that should seem to her like a failure of love or kindness to her _____ I shall at any rate remain in Albany but a short time -- I do not mean to go there before the middle of Feb’y -- -- My beloved Brother -- again and again I thank you for the kind interest you have expressed in my being with you this winter -- -- Oh may I be more thankful to the God of all my mercies for such a Brother _____ I received a long letter yesterday from our Coz Eliz' -- she speaks of her Father’s being in NYork, and expresses a hope that she should hear by him of your prosperity and happiness -- I could not help rejoicing in the thought that she was by that time in possession of so valuable a proof of your remembrance -- She writes to me often, & writes charmingly -- Oh that the ‘Basket & the Store' of our beloved Charles might be so blessed as to enable him to share them with her -- -- Our friends here are all well -- excepting -- Charles & Thaddeus Pomeroy, who are slightly indisposed -- Adieu my dear Brother Heaven bless thee, Your's trulyCMS --

Stockbridge May 17th 1814 The first letter that I write my dear Sister, is as it should be to you -- and if I had written as often as I have thought of you since the long lingering look I gave you, as you left the Dock, you would have folios enough to tire you, a larger number than my arithmetic could compass -- . You know Doctor Johnson has said, an hour may be tedious, but it cannot be long -- . I thought of this sage observation fifty times during our quick passage, which notwithstanding was inexpressibly tedious, -- The people around me seemed like so much clay, that the Spirit had never warmed or touched, and had it not been for poor Mrs Louis, and good little "Lu” I should have slept all the way in self-defence, that I might have dreamt of you & those around you -- The Shaker usages of the steam boat, excluded Theodore and Robert from our Cabin, and the storm prevented my meeting them on Deck, so that I had no society but little Bob who like me was heartily tired of his condition -- -- We arrived at Hudson at 3 O’clock, and didnot leave there until Thursday Morning The Country is arrayed in her bridal robes, and I think I never enjoyed its freshness and beauty more than during our ride from Hudson. We often wished you were with us my dear Frances to breathe the fragrant air, to listen to the sweet notes of the birds as they seemed to welcome the glorious sun, as he poured his golden beams upon the “fruit tree tops” -- This is the Season when all Nature sends forth her hymn of praise to her munificent Creator, and speaks to Man the sweet assurance that he too shall have his day of renovation, when his “leaf shall no more wither” You my dear Sister have so much of the Poet's relish of such scenes, that I could wish you were never debarred from the enjoyment of them -- Little Bob is like you in this, as in almost every thing else -- He stands by my window, counting the birds comparing their plumage and their notes, and expatiating with all the eloquence he is Master of, upon the beautiful green of Uncle Charles’ lot, and the “pretty pink flowers on the apple trees” -- -- -- But I beleive I was giving you an account of our journey, and like most Travellers I have wandered from the turnpike road, to the fields of my fancy, an excursion which you will probably find very dull -- -- We arrived here just in time to partake of Eliza’s dinner -- Her household are all well -- -- We didnot come to our own home until Friday and then I engaged with zeal in my domestic Duties that I might stifle recollections of which you know the bitterness -- -- Blessed be God -- Tho our Parents are gone from us their spirit is with us and still lives in the love and kindness that reigns among us -- Every spot around me is sacred, and recalls the remembrance of some act of kindness or some endearment of affection. -- -- -- -- Monday Morning I have posted Bob off, tho’ he went most ‘unwillingly to school’ -- -- Harry is in fine for Market -- His business confines him to Lenox He passed Saturday with us, but has gone up again today -- I found poor Sarah very sick, I fear in a dangerous way. She is unable to do anything at all What I am to do I know not, I have played Lady so long that I donot return to domestic drudgery with a very good grace -- -- . Poor Uncle Doctor sinks under the weight of his sorrows -- I beleive his warfare is almost finished and, I am sure that henceforward is laid up for him a crown of glory.” -- -- Theodore leaves us on Wednesday. My best love to Susan, if she is in Town -- I hope to get a letter from Eloise tomorrow, which I shall answer imme’y -- My love to her, and to Nancy and regards to my other friends -- more or less -- I wish you would purchase for any sum within 10/ a book for Frances Jones, of a religious character, and send it by the first conveyance to Albany, together with my receipt Book, and little account Book -- The latter I beleive I left on the shelf in my room -- -- Little Bob is talking already of the time when his Papa and Mama are coming -- My Love to your Husband and Children & beleive me dear Frances ever yours aff'yCMS --

text: Albany April 20th 1810 Fryday Eve'g I didnot know my dearest Frances till I received your letter today, that Catharine had been seriously ill. Robert mentioned her indisposition, but so slightly that I hardly thought of it a second time. I rejoice indeed in her recovery, but at such a distance our sympathies are feebly affected; it is a humbling fact, that our senses are the avenues to our hearts, we must see the flushed cheek, and hear the groan of anguish before our feelings can be awakened to comprehend even a Mother’s sufferings -- I confess I have sometimes thought of our little Kate’s excessive loveliness with that superstitious pain which dictates the fear that such sweetness cannot be permanent. However in spite of this vulgar presentiment, I trust Kate will one of these days be one of the wisest, best, and happiest matrons in all Christendom. I thank her for her remembrance of her Aunty, beleive me it caused a warmer glow somewhere in the vicinity of my heart, than all the drawing room compliments I ever received. As to Theodore’s prediction about his Aunt Susan I think it is a stronger proof of his tenderness for her than of his possessing cassandrian powers -- I wrote a long letter to my dear Eben a few days since, and intreated his Uncle Hal to bring him to Albany; today we have heard that Eliza and Harry will be here tomorrow, but not a word of my darling boy, so I must relinquish the hope of seeing him -- I wonder my dear Frances if you love him more than I do. Is it your habit and your delight to think of him every night, to wish for him every day? -- You have other Children, I have but one, do not be alarmed at my claiming him. My power over him is that of affection exclusively, & it must yield to the deadening influence of separation, yours cannot. Susan has relinquished all hopes of a New York visit -- We shall be involved in all the hurly burly of moving just at the time that either Bleecker or Sedgwick must be in NYork. Theodore goes the Western Circuit the first of June, in short all of his arrangements would be incompatible with the delightful one of seeing you -- I must take leave of you for the present, we are going to take tea at Mrs Banyer’s if you are not already discouraged you shall have a nocturnal offering -- I found myself so “gravelled for lack of matter” that I determined to depend on the evening for some glimmerings of intellect, but Sue has robbed me of all hope of this nature by the following request -- SheSusan has heard that there is an India ship arrived, and she wishes you to select from its Cargo, cambric of the quality you sent me, enough for two coat dresses, made to wrap with trimmings of the same -- She does not care how cheap you get it provided it is a fine as mine -- 1 yd and 1/2 of fine hook muslin for handkerchiefs -- In addition to what she wants for the dresses, trimmings, &c, she want a yard for I don’t know for what -- Since I am on on the subject of dresses, trimmings &c &c let me thank you for all the trouble you have taken for me, I am perfectly satisfied with every thing and only dissatisfied that I have not in my power to return these favors -- I mentioned to you that I would send the money for the shoes, but I beleive they may as well be charged -- You didnot let me know the price of Mrs Symmes's muslin -- I wish there was some philosophy in vogue that would free us from the slavery of these petty wants -- Nothing less than the “genius of universal emancipation” will affect it, and I am afraid that even this wonder working genius has no microscopic eye to discern the pigmy chains that bind us in this debasing dependence – These aspirations after heroic indifference are nothing more nor less than the consequence of a provoking disappointment of my Mantua maker -- so you see that I am not free from, but irritated by my chains -- You have heard of Miss Thompson my dear Frances, indeed I recollect your volunteering as her champion last summer -- She is a woman I think of much merit and some genius, as a proof of it I will copy for you a little impromptu which she sent me this morning -- She was here last evening, when I returned from a pedestrian excursion, during which I had met a little stranger whose beauty and loveliness had interested me extremely -- The following lines were suggested by the incident. How knows the gentle timid dove, To find its fond & faithful love; The sweet light-loving Lark to rise, As soon as morn unveils the skies; Or Philomel at evening hour, To seek the lone and silent bow’r? Or how the breathing blushing rose, Her fragrant bosom to unclose, To meet, the Sun’s warm genial pow’r, Or lave her in the dewey show’r? Or how the lilly’s slender stem, To bend its bright and snowy gem, In matchless loveliness beside, The meadow’s little silv'ry tide? Tis Sympathy by bounteous Heav'n, To ev’ry mode of being giv'n: That draws each to its destined goal, As if by one informing soul: ‘Twas this the little Frances drew, To fix her artless eyes on you; ‘Twas sympathy of youth & charms, That first impelled her to your arms: And Innocence almost divine, That gave her cherub lip to thine ‘Twas sweet benevolence that prest, Her guileless bosom to your breast, Whose answering purity my fair, Had almost held her ever there -- Now my dear Sister if the pleasure this little offering of Miss T muse, imparted to me was produced by my interest in the incident, or by my vanity, and not from any intrinsic merit it possesses, I beg you will not let your Husband laugh at it, I am bound by all the laws of honor and gratitude to protect its reputation. He may laugh at me as much as he pleases, but he must not point the shafts of ridicule at poor Miss Thompson, who has not vanity (which I have) as a coat of Mail to repel them -- By rights my dear Frances you should be President of the Synod, for you certainly extend your patronage to the whole body of presbyterian divinity -- Your protegé shall be attended to -- I will remember to forget that I heard him preach once, and go to hear him again -- Theodore will call upon him, and if he has a wife Sue will pay her respects to her Thank my dear Bob for his last letter, I will answer it shortly -- You will absolutely get a horror of my folios, so with love to my dear Brother I will bid you good night Yours most affly C M Sedgwick

Stockbridge Jan 12th 1800 My Dear Papa Last week I received a letter from you which gave me inexpressible pleasure. you sayed you supposed that I had enjoyed the pleasure of Sister Eliza’s and the children company but I hadnot when I received your letter it was such very poor sleighing we didnot expect them but My Dear Papa can you conceive of the pleasure we felt when hearing a sleigh drive up and going out perceived that Sister Eliza and her dear children were in it We were almost to happy Theodore had arrived two or three days before Mr Watson that afternoon judge of our pleasure I thought if you Henry and Robert were here & Mama was well our happiness would be complete. you sayed that we should derive more pleasure from their company in two hours than you would this whole winter indeed My Dear Papa I can verily beleive you I should be willing to impart to you my happiness on this occasion but it is impossible I see indeed I think I see in Mr Watson every thing that is amiable I am very much pleased with him indeed we are all of us Mama sends her love to you she speaks better than ever she did I think Theodore sends his love for you _____ Your affectionate Dutiful Daughter Catharine Maria Sedgwick

Boston Nov 19th 1804 I have neglected to write you my dear Mama only because I thought Papa,s letters would give you more pleasure than mine possibly could. To address you from Boston is entirely new to me and I feel that I have a thousand things to communicate which would interest and please you, but there are a thousand other things, which require my immediate attention, & occupy that time which I wish & ought to devote to you. -- -- I have become one of Mr Payne family , and Pupils, & am very well contented and pleased with my new situation. I have a French Master who attends me three times a week, and who by the by I expect every moment to be summoned to & a very excellent one I assure you. -- -- Mrs Tucker treats me as a child, and evinces her affection for you by the kindest attention to me: her Daughters are extremely amiable, and very kind to me. -- -- Mrs Quincey is as good a woman as she always was, and towards me is exactly as you would wish a Sister to be. -- Papa,s friends have been extremely polite to me, & have showed me all possible attention, almost innumerable are the invitations I have received & between my school and my company I have more than my handsful. I received my dear Lucy,s letter and sincerely thank her for it. I shall answer it by Papa. I was surprised that I didnot receive more letters by Mr Bidwell. I hope my friends in Stockbridge have not already forgotten me. -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- I beg you my dear Mama to remember me affectionately to Aunt DwightPoor Luce dear Charles and little Egbert, – Mrs Donalds EvelineJennyJoh & Cato!!!! -- -- -- Cousin E must not be forgotten. -- Beleive my beloved Mother ever your affectionate Child C M S

Stockbridge Novr 23rd 1815 Thursday Morning, dear Jane finds me thinking of you, which has indeed been my occupation, Morn, noon, and dewey eve’ ever since I left you -- -- To you my dear friend, to my dear Louisa, and to your excellent Brother I owe every expression of gratitude that can be dictated by a heart which appreciates your characters, and feels your kindness -- -- Could I send that heart to you, it would tell its own tale of thankfulness and love; but I cannot bear that words, which from my pen will not breathe, should be its Interpreter -- -- My deeds dear Jane shall speak for me, and when you come, a Company of Angels, into my little ‘Paradise’ you will see a memorial of the happy days I have passed with you -- We found our poor little steed perfectly insufficient to the burden imposed on him; his intentions were the best in the world, but we had to do with his corporeal part -- -- We did not arrive at Worcester ‘til Eight O’clock, & the next day we worked industriously to get to our Cousin Foster’s at Brookfield before night. -- And there dear Jane we sojourned with our good kindred, who were indeed more ‘than kind’ ‘til after breakfast monday morning; when with a parting ‘God speed’ and a bright sky, we pursued our way, and arrived safely at the close of day at Col’ Dwight’s -- -- Tuesday afternoon we came as far as Westfield to husband the strength of poor Whitey -- -- --Yesterday taking ‘patience in our tribulation’ we resumed our snail progress. The horse to all human perception was on his last legs, when at the foot of the mountain we met Jo, “you know Jo”. Charles had dispatched him with Sprightly, and “you know Sprightly” or if you do not, Helen does, to accelerate our progress -- Don Roderick the Goth didnot feel a warmer glow of joy at sight of his ‘own good Orelio’ than warmed our hearts when our noble mountain steed winding down the steep declivity appeared before us -- -- It was like a transition from one element to another; the dear animal bore us as joyfully as if Charles had breathed his own living soul into her -- -- We found our own family well, but the whole village clad in mourning and sorrow, for one of the saddest bereavements that has ever afflicted it. . The Father and Mother of six young Children have died within eight days -- They were in themselves indispensible to their children, I should have said, but our Father in heaven has declared himself the orphan’s God -- -- -- Pardon me dearest Jane for communicating to your sympathizing spirit the pain that other’s woes inflict, but I needed some excuse for writing a hasty and shabby letter, and to you it will be a sufficient one that my morning has been occupied in a visit to the Mourners -- could not suffer the stage to go without a line -- -- Charles begs his regards may be sent to the whole family, and Harry after Mrs M. (always first) desires in primitive phrase, to be suitably presented to the Institution of the Friendlys My best love to your Brother & Sister -- Helen and Julia -- Mrs Fales -- &c &c &c -- God bless you my own dear Jane --CMS -- For pity’s sake read ‘Roderick the Goth’ as we have done and think it is the noblest poem of modern times, as we have thought Dear Jane do write me very soon

Stockbridge Nov' 12. Thursday --My dear Robert I was very much pleased with your complaint that we didnot write often enough, because it the complaint proves that you think of us more than we deserve -- I thought I had written quite as often as you could desire to hear, and should have been as much puzzled to know why you should complain as Solomon, or some of the old testament worthies want to know, why a ‘living man’ complained -- -- I beleive my last letter to you was written just before I set out for Conn’t -- I found our good Uncle much better than I expected tho suffering a little with the gout -- The eruption on his nose which they apprehended to be a cancer, is now thought to be a wen -- These are the common evils of old age -- The necessary pangs that attend the taking down the beautiful structure, that in youth, and health, seems so fit a ‘palace for the Soul’ -- -- Uncle enjoys perfect peace and cheerfulness -- I have never seen him when he appeared happier -- -- -- He still insists that you had grown much taller when he saw you last, and lost your french look entirely -- -- You know to be small & to look like a Frenchman, would be the most ‘calamitous concurrence’ of physical evils that Uncle could conceive of -- -- I am very desirous Jane should see Uncle at home, in all his patriarchal grandeur and simplicity, should hear Pamela ‘Sesame’ in perfect unison with their rocks and surly hills -- & see ‘Mr Ben’ and ‘Ame’ and all the train of Hollebards and Wilcoxs, that make up an establishment as amusing to a philosophic eye as the Castle of “King Corney” -- I went to Litchfield & passed a night with old Mrs Edwards -- She seemed very much gratified to see me, & received me with as much tenderness as if I had been her only Child -- She begged me to give her “kind love” to my Brothers Harry and Robert and tell them she wished them prosperity and happiness -- -- I found all at our own dear home well -- home it is to us all, and I feel as if it was as much the resting-place of my Brothers hearts as mine -- I am no where happier than sitting here by our little comfortable stove, and if I could have my beloved Brothers and Sisters all here ‘winter and rough weather’ should never enter our doors _____ Frances is still in Albany, & will probably remain there two or three weeks -- -- -- We are all well here, a blessing that ought not to be spoken of or thought of without gratitude to our Heavenly Father -- Do write to me my dear Robert it is a long time since I have received more than a line from you -- Eliza said you was kind enough to say you would send us a Coffee Grecque -- our old strainer is entirely worn out, so that we cannot use it at all -- We have a good coffee-pot if you could therefore procure the strainer without the additional expense of the coffee-pot it would do just as well -- If you could send it to Frances she could bring it down with her -- -- Will you also my dear Brother, get us lbs 4 of Souchong-tea & charge it to me I would not trouble you, but we cannot get it tolerable in Albany, nor drinkable here -- -- I never tuck in such commissions at the end of a letter without thinking of your strictures upon such requests smuggled under three pages of friendship -- Dear Robert, if I could I would do it for you -- But it has pleased Providence to make you the giver May you fully experience that benediction “It is more blessed to give than to receive -- Love to all -- Tell Theodore I shall write to him soon -- God bless you all -- yours truly CMS T will write you soon a statement of th Cloth --

text: Stockbridge Dec'r 28'th1807 Fatigued to death, my dear Frances, by the vulgar employment, of making mince pies, and almost overcome by my constitutional disease, viz sleepiness, I seat myself at my writing desk, to instruct and delight you with the animation of intelligence, and the sprightliness of vivacity -- In truth my Sister, I am either turning misanthrope, or so much addicted to indolence (H Penfield might furnish me with a thirdalternative) that no living person except yourself, has power to rouse me to the exertion of wielding a goose quill -- Even you can go no farther -- You can not produce effects without a cause -- Instinctively I make letters, and connect them till they become words, but mere “words, words, words” In this state of absolute torpidity, I cannot do you a greater favor my dear Frances than to suspend my labors till a New Year, after wishing you peaceful slumbers and cheerful dreams -- -- -- 1808 The Morning of the New Year has arrived, not, illumined with the bright rays of a genial Sun, but overcast by tempestuous, menacing clouds -- I trust this may not be emblematical of the color of your life, my dear Sister through the present Year -- Could my most fervent prayers avail you aught, each new day should bring with it new enjoyments; without one cloud of sorrow, to dim for a moment your felicity -- To My Brother my best wishes are of course extended -- May my little Theodore trudge on in the path of literature, and find it quite full of roses, without thorns, in the shape of hard words, and birchentwigs. My sweet little namesake is already possessed of so much loveliness, that I know not whether to wish her any thing but a continuation of it -- -- Papa arrived at home last evening, and notwithstanding, the roads were never in a more execrable state, he is not in the least degree fatigued. -- How much should we rejoice in the renovation of the health of this most beloved and excellent Parent -- I wish he could effect his visit to you this winter, that my judgment plays the rebel to my inclinations I confess -- So long a journey at this Season of the year is very formidable to youth and robust health -- It is more than Papa ought to encounter -- However should the Season prove propitious I shall be very far from opposing his wishes. Immured as our dear Hal is here, the jaunt is very desirable for him -- It is most painful to see so much genius, and excellence languish in obscurity -- It is absolutely necessary that Harry should come in collision with society, to discover his superior pretensions to the fair damsels of fame -- He is now in Albany, in the great world -- He had the most earnest, and flattering invitations to join his friends, and taste for a little while the pleasure of this metropolis -- -- Absolutely my dear Frances if I was put to the test I could not tell whether I had written two lines in connection, nor the subject of any two lines in my letter -- I left it in the morning to discharge my domestic duties, and greet my neighbors with the salutations of the new year -- After dining at the Doctors I returned to complete but was interrupted by the most unwelcome and vexatious visitors -- This evening I seated myself with as much serenity, and patience as I could summon to my aid; but I have found myself somewhat disturbed by Papa, and Eben, who are perambulating the room hand in hand; Papa relating the most pathetic tales to his little favorite, and the latter frequently interrupting the narration with most artless exclamations of surprise and pity. Was he good Grand Papa? Did every body in the world love him? Oh! I am sorry he was drowned, I could swim -- But I cannot bring this little interesting Being before you in his thousand varied attitudes excellent attention, and animated love -- -- -- Susan’s silence is incomprehensible to me -- Formerly she was punctuality embodied I learn too that I am not the only person, towards whom that ardor of her friendship is abated -- I could remind her that once she was wont to quote the rules of fair Rosalind on the subject -- of a Lover’s punctuality, and would fain have found a precedent, whereby she might condemn a certain friend of ours -- But now times are changed and T avers in thelanguage of complaint that he has written 5 times, and received but one solitary letter in return -- My love to her, in spite of all these unexampled injuries -- To Matilda my most affectionate rembrance -- -- Papa has instructed me to say every thing from him to you, to Mr Watson, and to Susan -- I must tell you that in consequence of his weariness he shall defer writing till next week -- -- Eliza continues remarkably well -- She thanks you for your letter and was very desirous of answering it this week, but owing to excessive weak eyes, she thought it was most prudent to omit it -- Miss Frances Susan acquires new beauties every day, and promises to be no unworthy namesake of the fair Laidies whose titles she bears -- -- Mumbetwho is never an unimportant personage now figures in her element -- She begs me to “member her love to Mrs Miss Watson” -- She was delighted with the testimony of dear Susan’s kind dispositions towards her -- -- I had a great deal of trouble convincing her of the reality of the present -- But she does not express to Theodore for making him I believe I have nothing to you since of Howe and Susan -- although I have intended it every time I have written you -- Susan’s health is a little improved, at least she flatters herself it is -- but I fear she is doomed forever to suffer the affliction of ill health -- Caroline is with her, and is a very sprightly and pleasing girl -- I find their society is a very copious source of enjoyment to me -- Charles felt himself hurt, by your complaint of him -- He desires to be particularly remembered to you, and to Mr Watson. My love to Mr Watson, and kisses to the children – Do my sister write me -- Yours most Sincerely C M Sedgwick

New York April 26 --My dearly beloved Frances -- I thank you most sincerely for all your kind letters -- May there never be any thing but kindness between us -- The few last day’s sad experience have drawn me very near to my dear Sisters and Brothers -- and I think I have realized more than I ever did before, the great change that awaits us, and the infinite importance of preparing for it -- Oh My Sister -- What is this life? -- what, but the means of attaining another Oh May I never forget the lessons that I read on the pale pale angel face of my sweet friend -- All that life could give she possessed -- and blessed be God more, infinitely more, that portion which is now her joyous inheritance -- Is it not my dear Frances a most mournful mournful event -- I can weep for myself for I have lost a christian friend -- a sincere and affectionate friend; but when I think of her poor Sisters, of Mrs Banyer! I am silent with awe --. Nancy said to me ‘I can hear that voice which says, ‘Be still and know that I am God” -- -- It is a singularly solemn dispensation of Providence -- They have been enabled to receive it in humility, and resignation, and while their hearts were nigh to bursting, they acknowledged that God didnot leave them without the tokens of his Mercy, and with their burning lips they said ‘thy will be done’ -- yes my dear Frances, I heard Mrs Banyer utter those words when she was hanging over her darling, in indescribable agony, a few moments after she expired -- -- -- Sally was every thing to her Sister. Child, companion -- She has soothed and cheered her thro’ many days of sickness and sorrow, She was indeed to every-one kind and tender and good, and oh with what sweet patience and fortitude, what truly christian fortitude and composure, she endured the suffering it pleased God to lay upon her -- Her senses were perfect to the last -- About an hour before she expired her Brother said to her My dear Sister you are going to be very happy! I trust so Brother said she, but oh it is very hard to leave so many near and dear friends, my dear old Father. My dear Brothers and Sisters, and ‘oh the sweet children’ -- He said your Savior is with you thro’ the dark valley -- Yes said she but it is a dark dark valley -- She repeatedly said ‘God knows best -- Let us put our whole trust in Him -- God hath taken her to himself! Her pure spirit is removed from all temptation and evil -- She has entered into rest, into joy -- My dear Sister -- pray for me that I may be taught by the Providence of God -- That my heart may not be hardened after it -- May we be enabled to honor our Master here; and be prepared for the solemn hour of Death, when it shall please him to appoint it -- I was with Mrs Banyer and Nancy a great deal, I never saw so deep a grief as theirs, and yet they were wonderfully and graciously supported Nancy is almost an Angel -- but Mrs Banyer from the very hopelessness and helplessness of her grief, as it relates to any enjoyment in this world, excites a deeper commiseration than Nancy -- -- Let us pray My dear Sister that they may be able to comprehend -- -- the length, and 'breadth, and height and depth, and to know the love of Christ" _____ Did not I tell you that the Doctor enquired after you, and very tenderly? It was a strange omission -- Yesterday he preached all day, and looked nearly as well as ever -- -- He alluded in his prayer to the melancholy event of the past week, and he said with his peculiar energy of feeling ‘We must have something that cannot die I have no doubt he will visit you this Summer -- Anna Warner has been to see me several times She charming Woman -- and I beleive they are highly blessed in their union -- -- Eloise writes in fine spirits -- She is going to Bolton to pass the Summer with Mrs Channing, who is going to take a house there -- near to her Brother’s -- -- Eloise speaks most affectionately of you, and says she feels an unabated interest in you and your concerns -- My dearest Frances -- you excite all our tenderness, and command that approbation of the heart, which it is equally blessed to give be able to give, and to deserve to receive -- -- The love of the dear Children penetrates my heart God bless them and makes their souls temples for his Spirit -- My dear Sister -- I have partly executed your commissions, I shall enclose an account of the amount of all the articles that you may know they do not amount to a great deal -- Robert dear Robert so far from your exceeding his wishes, told me to get whatever I thought you wanted, whether you had included it in the list or not -- -- -- I should not have chosen to have got my dear Kate’s crape on the same piece with Maria -- but I was obliged to make that arrangement in order to get an exchange of the silk -- The Shopkeepers are very unwilling to exchange cut Crape, except into equal parts -- The silk I had a good deal of difficulty in getting off -- I shall get a crape or Italian Silk for Fanny -- As Maria didnot specify the quantity of crape -- you must suit your convenience and let her have the remainder -- They allowed me 7/per yd for the Silk -- There was 7 yds -- of course you are entitled to 7yds of the crape -- but you may take less, if you choose, and charge Maria with the rest -- The crape was $15, you have a right to $6.88 -- cents worth of it -- I didnot think it worth while to attempt to change the gingham -- Harry had some waistcoats, which he had laid by to send to the Boys -- I therefore have purchased but two -- The green one for my dear Ebb, I got under its original cost, in consequence of its being a small pattern -- the other I am of did-not suit me -- I had looked every where, and could find nothing that did, and at last got that in desperation -- I have looked a good deal for Maria’s shawl, and have only found one which I think will do, It is low in consequence of being a little spotted but I think not materially spotted -- If I cannot do better I shall get it, and I beg you will convince her that I have taken all proper pains -- I have given $6 for the shawl Jane continues perfectly well, and seems to be without a single anxiety! -- Both she and Harry often wish you was here, and are determined you shall be -- How much do I think of you in your old seat at church, and in the sound of that voice that has so often kindled your glowing soul -- -- On reading over my letter, I fear it will almost unintelligible to you -- It was written as I felt, and strong sorrowful feeling, does not express itself calmly -- -- You will probably have letters from Robert -- His heart is always warm to you dear Sister -- -- -- -- God bless you and your’s my beloved Frances -- Beleive me ever truly your'sCMS -- I have no time now to send the bills -- I hope you will like the Italian silk for Fanny instead of the crape --
