text: Albany March 27th 1810 I received my dear Frances by Mr Webb your very kind, and I would add emphatically your very welcome letter -- I am sorry my dearest Sister to repress your tenderness by a confession, mortifying & humiliating to me but nevertheless due to truth. On no subject would I voluntarily be guilty of hypocrisy, and on that which involves all the importance of our existence, I should shrink from the slightest insincerity -- You misunderstood my last letter, I exposed to you a state of mind & feeling, produced not by religious impressions, but by the conviction of reason -- I do my dear Frances feel my utter destitution, of any “claim to reward” my entire helplessness as it regards any merit of my own, and entire dependance on mercy, mediation, and atonement, -- I should be unworthy the tenderness that dictated your letter if I didnot acknowledge, that my heart is not filled with that entire reverence and love for the Supreme Being which he requires from his Creatures I am utterly destitute of those holy affections which should be so completely incorporated with our Being as to bebecome a part of it -- I have not a fixed belief on some of the most material points of our religion -- There have been moments of my life when I have had a lively, importunate though alas transient interest awakened in serious things, but the cares and the pleasures of this world have operated on these sudden impulses as the “thorns” in the parable -- -- Change of scene or society has induced me to shake off these impressions, as fetters that constrained my vivacity, and to venture forward again forgetful of theexcellent the precious Anchor I had so lightly thrown away. -- -- Do not my dear Frances, think me ungrateful for your solicitude on this subject, beleive me insensible cold & indifferent as I appear, and as indeed I really am, I reckon among the choicest blessings of that gracious Providence whose beneficence towards me is infinite, the example of our sainted Mother, of my dear Eliza & yourself -- _____ _____ Matilda leaves us in the steam Boat tomorrow -- I need not tell you that I regard her going as a serious diminution of my pleasures -- However nothing short of the most unpardonable selfishness could induce us to express a wish that she should prolong her visit -- Her poor Mother is almost entirely debarred from the society of her favorite Child, and compelled to look for her comforts in the narrow sphere of domestic occupations. Matilda eminent as she is for her filial affection dreads a return to Oakhill at this dreary Season as she would the toothache. Is not it melancholy my dear Frances that those duties which nature instinctively suggests to us should ever become irksome? -- -- I received the articles by Webb the muslin is quite too fine to trim the dress I wish you would send me a yard of british muslin a 5 or 6/-- The lace is beautiful and the right I was disappointed in not getting the Frenchman’s shoes the morocco were too small. I have disposed of all but the lilac, and if you will not be out of patience I shall get you to supply their place -- I wish you would get dark grass green if you can, if you cannot, the shade you sent are very handsome, and two pair of lead color, the pair for Sue very dark -- I shall send the same shoe for a measure, and I wish you would get my kid exactly the size, and the morocco and Sue’s kid, a very little larger. I would rather you would send the bill of these last, and I will send you the money, because added to the others, they would swell my shoe bill immensely. I wish Robert would look on the steam boat Books and find somebody coming up on Saturday to whom he can trust them. I really want them Mr Webb says that little Bob was sick. I hope he is incorrect as you say nothing of it -- My love to my Brothers, and the dear Children -- Do write me dearest Sister when you have leisure -- Yrs most affly C M Sedgwick.

Stockbridge Saturday Evening Nov' 1818 -- The habit of writing often to you my dear Brother seems to engender the want -- It will be hard, if my habits become your plagues ‘till they do, I shall indulge them to my hearts-content -- Mr ‘Ball and Bassett’ has not yet returned, when he does, I trust we shall have some return to the mail we sent by him. Arrivals from your quarter are as anxiously looked for here as any arrival in the Isle of Sky -- The anticipation serves us for a topic at breakfast, dinner, & tea, for a week at least -- The letters we write come in with a thousand other matters of interest, and are like traces on the sand, effaced as soon as made. Is it not so? -- -- I heard from Eliz’ yesterday -- She says “I cannot delay transmitting through you to your Brother Robert an acknowledgement of the receipt of a beautiful Edition of Byron’s works, which he sent me by Papa. Will you say to him that they will be classed among my valuables, of incidental as well as intrinsic worth; but tho’ the books are so very elegant and Byron a favorite Poet his little note beginning “Dear Coz” was worth them all. When he shall have found a Lady, whom he deems worthy to participate his existence (of which he confesses there is not an impossibility) with her, perhaps, I may have the pleasure of depositing my goodwill to her better half” -- a pretty long quotation -- I would have saved myself the trouble and given you the pleasure of reading her whole letter, if I had any other conveyance than the Mail -- While I am on the subject of letters, I will tell you that I rec’d quite a long and pleasing one last week from Miss Dillingham -- She says, “the Abbe Sicard affirms that Mr Clerc must return to Paris in the Spring” -- so that I suppose our Deaf & Dumb must then lose his valuable services. Probably, he is to be the successor of the old Abbe, who is 72. What a blessing it is that there is a wisdom that can make even the dumb eloquent I do not know when I have been more impressed with the degradation, of making the whole Being subserve the purposes of mere animal wants than when I was at Cornwall -- A child had been taken to the asylum from a family there, as a charity Scholar -- -- Her friends were deploring the necessity of suffering her to remain in the school, because she “would not know nothing about business” and her old Grandmother said, would be ‘just like any Lady good for nothing at all’ -- -- Timothy’s coronation day occurs on Wednesday. The meeting of the allies in the Champs Elyices or any other grande circonstance, could not be more magnificent than is this in the eye of the Hero of the scene. He seems determined to indemnify himself for the loss of the organ of sight, by magnifying every object to his mental vision -- He has summoned no less than ten Clergymen, and as many delegates to compose his Council, besides sending letters of invitation far & near to his acquaintance. Green River must enlarge her boundaries, if the North does not keep back & the South refuse to give up half he has invited -- I have never quite made up my mind whether vanity was the greater torment or comfort -- but I rather think its gratifications have all the unsatisfactoriness of fictions, & its disappointments are very sober certainties -- Such a Man as W. continually walketh in a 'vain show', and tho’ palaces may glitter, & Goddesses stalk around him Ithuriel’s spear in some form or other is continually dissolving the baseless fabrics, and leaving all a waste -- -- Who would not prefer the Inheritance of one of the beatitudes that are promised to the Disciples of the meek & lowly Jesus! -- -- We are all well, or mending -- Little Charles Pomeroy has been very sick with a swelling under the knee -- We were very anxious for some days, but he has been lanced, and he is quite relieved -- .Charles is sleeping profoundly on the Sofa. He charged me to leave space enough for a postscript -- -- which I am the more willing to do as it is Saturday night, when you may remember sleep instead of a kind Nurse, is always a Tyrant -- -- Good-night dearest Robert. May you have such visions as good health and conscience at peace with all man can bestow _____

Albany Feby 26 1816 -- No my dear Sister -- no apparent neglect ever would induce me to beleive that in you the feeling that prompts kindness is wanting -- -- I have indeed been exceedingly anxious to hear from you, particularly on account of Mr Watson’s sickness -- -- Our sweet friend, Sally mentions you in all her letters, and through that medium we have heard that your Husband has quite recovered. May God in mercy sanctify to his afflicted spirit all his dealings with him -- and may you my beloved Sister experience that the ties that unite you to be bonds of peace -- -- I should think the most judicious, and under all circumstances the pleasantest plan you could adopt, would be the one recommended by Mr Hudson -- The same means that in NYork would circumscribe you extremely, would be comparative affluence at Stockbridge -- -- The separation from your sons, I know will be positive suffering to you, but if by it dear Sister you can perhaps secure the means of a more future comfortable family establishment, when your Children will be farther advanced in life, and need those very things, the absence of which, they will not even be conscious of at present -- Catharine will have advantages from your leisure and instructions, and every pleasure in the society of her Cousins, that her moderate desires can covet -- Our dear little Bob with our Minstrel, with his sentimental love of solitude, his love of nature, the instinct of a Child of nature, will find in our meadows and groves enough to fill his whole heart -- -- This is no romancing, for you and I dear Sister, have seen him seek and pluck the wild flowers with all the taste of sentiment if not with all the discrimination of philosophy -- -- Little Frances is at the happy age that does not look beyond the present & the only age I beleive that finds compliance with the Apostle’s injunction “In whatsoever state you are therewith to be content” easy . . -- To your Husband I know this must be a sore trial; but I trust he will that quietness of spirit given to him, that nothing can alter, and none disturb -- -- -- -- We have had Mr Cummings preaching here -- The Presbytery had received him again, I beleive on the pleas that insanity had caused his misconduct -- -- I heard him at Mr Bradford lecture room on Friday, and was extremely pleased with him -- On Sunday he preached again, in the morning a sermon that delighted every body -- -- almost verbatim from Jop Cady, and in the afternoon he preached the same sermon, for which he was dismissed at Newark-- -- He published it -- It was half purloined, and as if that was not enough, he had was guilty of direct falsehood, when charged with it -- the most charitable beleive that he is still insane -- It certainly is the most foolish villainy I ever heard of -- -- Albany is very pleasant this winter -- Our excellent Brother’s family is as happy as prosperity and love, sanctified by the blessing of God, can make them -- -- I can hardly express to you dear Frances, how the sentiment that Susan’s kindness inspire -- She is a most lovely Being -- -- -- Have you heard of poor Eliza’s affliction, in the dismission of Theodore from College -- -- She is an anxious and tender Mother and suffers with all the poignancy of a Mother sensibility on the subject -- Theodore has been excessively indolent ever since he has been at College No mental exertions can be expected from him -- -- -- I have not heard from Robert for some time, I must refer you to him my dear Frances for information. I am sincerely sorry for poor Eloise’s troubles, but if girls will fall in love, they must take the consequences -- -- -- Have you read Roderick yet? -- -- -- I am find myself quite too poor for the lace -- The muslin I beleive I can obtain here -- -- -- Susan sends her best love to you, and begs that you will not have any anxiety about answering her letters -- She says she shall write to you soon again -- Theodore and the Children send their love -- Mrs Symmes & Mrs Banyer who always enquires very affectionately for you -- -- Mr Bleecker begged me some time ago to tell you that he thought a great deal about you -- If Robert should be at NY -- Tell him I wrote to him at Boston on the 24th, a letter that if I could have taken such a liberty with old Jupiter, I should have borrowed Mercury to carry it ____ My dear Sister let me hear from you as often as you can -- Remember me most affy to your husband & children and all my friends -- Heaven bless you my dearest Frances Yours as everCMS --

Stockbridge July 7th 1807 By this time my dear Frances is initiated into all the complicated ceremonies of the Beau Monde. I confess I do not think there is much danger of your being intoxicated, with the pleasures that are hourly soliciting your acceptance, I rather fear that you will conjure up a thousand phantoms in the shape of burns, scalds, drownings, falls, and sickness indeed calamity in every form, that it ever appeared to the sickness loving imagination of Aunt Sergeant, to frighten away all that wears the aspect of enjoyment I hope better things of you my dear Sister, and as I think you possessed of reason, and some little rationality, I trust you will beleive my assurances of the welfare of our little flock -- If it were not too trite; and I think provoking an observation, I should say they were much better without than with you -- Hannah is extremely attentive and kind -- Theodore and Eben have lost their truant disposition, as to their improvement in erudition, I know nothing. Theodore told me yesterday with an air of vast complacency, that he read in Anchor: From this I should suspect he had made a retrograde movement. He has with wonderful facility transferred his affections from you to me, for the time being -- -- Little Kate has never cried one night since you “left” -- She sometimes wakes during the night -- -- Her bowels are not at all disordered and her teeth do not give her any trouble Your old friend Thomas Day, What old Tom,? no your Tom? aye, has beg been here ever since nine in the morning. just as I was dating my letter, my temper was somewhat ruffled by his sudden appearance. Now at two Oclock are going to dinner, and I have proceeded but just so far in my letter. He has made a day of it in the old Connecticut style. I wish in my heart you were at home, that you might with the chosen friend of your Youth, summon up “the Ghosts of your departed joys” -- I intended to have given you and Papa an epistle of “much pith and moment” but alas! my good intentions are always frustrated -- -- Mamahas been much more comfortable for the last four days and nights. She has had none of those distressing turns during the day, neither has she for several nights -- -- -- -- She rides regularly every day, and I know it is of essential service to her Tomorrow we hope for a “consummation, most fervently to be wished” from New York -- -- -- -- -- -- I wish Frances, if it is perfectly convenient to Papa you would request him to purchase the Minstrel and Mrs Montagu’s essay on the genius of Shakespear -- -- -- -- -- Remember us all most affectionately to Papa -- To the MrsT family my best love -- -- -- -- Yours &c my dear Sister CMS

New York Feby 22nd 1810 I do not know how I can better add my leaf to the wreath that is annually wove, for the Hero who has illustrated this day, than by devoting my time to his friend, & my beloved Father. -- The customary acts of celebration are performing, the common routine of a procession, oration, and dinner. Poor Bob left us this morning with a most vehement & anti-patriotic denunciation of a march through the fallen, and falling snow. This glow of republican enthusiasm must have suffered a melancholy diminution, since it was food to the hungry, & clothes to the half-naked soldiers of our Washington. As our Chymists would say, it has lost its igniting qualities for it will not even warm the fingers and toes of our modern patriots. Our Moderns too like Sancho have no relish for fighting on an empty stomach, & never even treat their imaginations to a field of Battle ‘till they have treated their appetites to all the luxuries of a City feast, and their passions to some few Bottles of valour-inspiring madeira, -- No doubt many of our self-created talking Heros will today for their Country bleed & die & lay in “honor’s bed”; men who I am sadly afraid if the “circumstance of war” should in reality occur to them, would earn no better berth than “honor’s truckle bed.” -- -- -- -- -- -- Mr Watson in a letter which we received yesterday mentions his determination of spending a night with you before his return. We are rejoiced at for his sake, for yours, and for ours -- You will not perhaps think that we can have any particular interest in any thing which can protract his return. But if you will recollect for a moment the worship of images and relics, you will not wonder that we shall have no small addition of happiness from Mr Watson's having seen you & heard you. We hear very irregularly from home -- If we had not had frequent experience of the truth of the old adage that “no news is good news” to cure us of the folly of apprehending evil, we should suffer extremely from this remissness of our friends. -- -- Now my dear Papa I am going to enter a formal complaint of the mal-conduct the grievous negligence of your youngest hope I had flattered myself with the sweet illusion that he had “too much grace to err” but his epistolary sins have convinced me that in “Adam’s fall, we sinned all” -- I know that this negligence always receives your severest reprobation, & that in your eyes at least all the water of the Housatonick cannot wash away its crimson hue -- -- Seriously my dear Papa Charles has not written one word to Frances for two years, knowing Frances’s sensibility at least as well as I do, it is unnecessary for me to tell you how much she is pained by this -- He has written but two letters this winter. This is a 'plain unvarnished tale" not to put him down, but to reform him -- I am very glad to hear Mrs Sedgwick has in a good degree recovered her health. She will now I presume be able to accompany you, on the next circuit -- a jaunt which from her long indisposition I thought she would be obliged to relinquish -- I am ashamed to say that I still intend to answer her kind long letter -- I have been very dissipated this week and really didnot feel in spirits to do it justice -- I beleive I have not yet had an opportunity of thanking Harriet for her very acceptable little gift. Tell her my dear Papa that I seldom use it -- without wishing to know the giver and to offer her my thanks impropria persona for gratuitous favor -- Have you seen Walsh’sreviewif you have, you no doubt think it an honor to american literature. I hope you are a subscriber for that, or the Edinborough review -- The latter I think is the most valuable as a literary journal the former for the high integrity of its political principles.. I had almost forgotten a serious promise I made old Mrs Hoffman the last time I saw her, -- She begged me to present her most friendly regards to you & tell you that she hoped tho' you had bought the new bible that you didnot beleive in it -- -- We are as happy as we can be separated from so many of our dear friends -- From my dear Frances I experience every kindness that her uncommon affection can bestow -- The Children talk a great deal of their favorite home and their dear Grandpapa -- -- -- I wrote to one Mrs Pomeroy three weeks ago, but she has not deigned to acknowledge the receipt of my letter -- -- -- -- Frances received a very affectionate letter from Betsy yesterday with a handsome pair of mocasins --as a peace offering I suppose I would not have omitted to mention this, because I am sure it will gratify you very much -- -- I wish you would write to her my dear Papa, for I am afraid she thinks her friends have all forgotten her -- Our love to all especiallyUncle Doctor’s family -- Ever yours Dear Papa C M Sedgwick There is a muslin bonnet from here for aunt Dwight which Mrs F left & the Judge could not take -- The Mail has come again and no letters

text: New York 27th Jany1809 I beleive my dear Papa that I have so firmly established my character for punctuality, and attention, that I am in no danger of forfeiting it, from my last week’s omission -- It was the all-controlling power of necessity, that prevented my then answering your very kind letter, a letter which excited emotions of the warmest gratitude for your parental, and affectionate wishes, on the New Year -- Indeed my beloved Parent in my relation to you, I have every cause for the most heartfelt gratitude, from my infancy to the present moment, your treatment of me has been a course of invariable indulgence, & uninterrupted tenderness -- -- -- -- -- We are delighted with the harmony and happiness that pervades our society at Stockbridge. Our new friend has received the tribute of the most flattering praise from every individual of the family. The Boys speak of her as possessing great benevolence, and the most uncommon kindness to all that come within the sphere of her influence -- I hope then in proportion as she confers happiness, she will receive it in return. If she is contented now in spite of the dreariness of Winter, she will surely be very happy in Summer -- -- -- -- Judge Benson left here, this morning for Albany, from whence he intends going very soon to Stockbridge, where I know he will be received with the most cordial hospitality -- He has omitted no kindness to me; and has bestowed much more time on his attentions than I could with any propriety have expected of him -- For all this, I feel extremely grateful and I should be delighted with an opportunity to evince it -- The fame of MrKane’s Ball has spread far and wide -- He is nobly generous, and in this instance, he has his reward, in the pleasure he has bestowed on his Guests -- -- -- We are very happy here, all in fine health and spirits Mr Watson’s business is of a nature to occupy him constantly, yet I beleive he feels very sensibly its diminution in consequence of the Embargo -- The suffering in this City from that execrable cause, is almost incredible, and the unparalleled exertion to releive it is most honorable to the Citizens -- Should they be enabled to carry their intentions into execution, the wretched objects of misery that now fill our streets will be completely expelled from them -- The melancholic and disastrous state of the brave Spaniards , will learn from the Newspapers, and I know person my dear Papa who will feel a commiseration for their sufferings than yourself I was the other day at the house of old friend of yours Mrs Popham, who spoke of you in terms of the most affectionate admiration. She has heard much of Mrs S and congratulates you on this accession to your happiness -- -- -- Why does not our dear Charles write us. He has been very long indebted to me but he seems resolved that I shall still remain his Creditor -- I received a very long, and a very welcome letter from Robert last week, the which I shall answer in due time. To my dear Harry I am also indebted -- -- -- Remember me most affectionately to all the family, great and small -- -- -- Beleive me my dear Papa with the most fervent prayers for your health and happiness Your affectionate Child Catharine M Sedgwick

text: Boston Wednesday Evening Dec'r 16th You know my dear Robert why I havenot written to any of you for some time past. Harry has preferred writing for three or four days, and I have consented to it from the belief that he would write more judiciously than myself -- Our dear Father passed last night very comfortably -- Today his countenance is much better -- Doctor Danforth says that the appearance of every thing is pleasing His most alarming symptoms have subsided -- For myself I see little ground for expecting any essential change immediately -- The evident tendency to dropsy, and the exhausted state of the constitution seem to me to forbid the indulgence certainly of sanguine hopes -- -- Two days ago I was extremely anxious that you should come on immediately -- but Papa is now so much better that our fears are quieted for the present You shall hear every day -- and you can then decide for yourself, better than we can for you I have felt my dear Brother the ineffable consolation of reposing myself entirely on the righteousness of my God and of committing our most beloved Parent to the arms of his everlasting Mercy -- For my dear Sister I feel deeply anxious, and I should have addressed this letter, to her if I had felt certain that you had communicated to her Papa’s situation -- I pray that she may keep her mind as quiet as possible -- that her apprehensions may be alleviated by her confidence in the justice of our God, and the compassion of our Redeemer -- -- My dear Robert the hand that united us is drawn closer by our common affliction -- . Let us hear from you very often -- My best love to my Brother -- Every thing that the tenderness and interest of our friends can suggest or apply is done for our dear Father -- Danforth encourages us very much -- Mrs Sedgwick -- Harry and Charles unite in love to you all God bless you dear Robert Ever yours CMS

Stockbridge Oct 20' 1817. With five Children and as many Adults buzzing about me dear Robert, I shall attempt to write you a line or two my dear Robert, tho’ I beleive you owe me one or two epistles --. A private Conveyance addresses itself so irresistibly to my love of oeconomy, and my love of prating, to you, that I cannot ‘win’ by it -- -- . . I write according to your newly-adopted motto “write anything, only write”. I have just completed a long letter to Aunt Effy in which I have circumstantially detailed all the obstacles that oppose my going to NYork this Fall -- as they are too tedious to repeat, I refer you to her. -- I have sent Aunt Effy a small pot of peppers -- I should have preferred that they should have stopped in Chambers, or Greenwich , but my obligation to la bonne petite veuve arof such a nature, as to render it very desirable to me to make some such return to them -- or rather to exhibit some such evidence of my sense of them -- I want very much to send you a Bottle of Cherry, and shall if I can contrive any mode of doing it safely -- It is very fine & willnot be the worse to you dear Robert from the consciousness of the kindness that provided the Cherries & from its being made by my hands and within these walls -- You feel all the force of the sentiment that animated the ‘Chieftain’, when he said he “would give more for one apple from the Garden of his Father’s house, than for all the grapes of France and all the almonds of Spain ” -- If I had a direct opportunity, I certainly would send Harry a Bottle of cream, the product of our beautiful little Heifer -- By the way do tell Harry that Charles has been offered for the little Calf to whose death he was advising; $10 and the Doctor advises not to take $20. She is pronounced by all the Amateurs a prodigious fine animal -- -- -- I am becoming very much interested in rustic concerns The succés of a fine Lady does not occupy more of her thoughts, than the result of Charley’s farming does of mine, neither is her heart more interested in the accumulation of Lovers, than mine is in the increase of my cream, and all the little matters of my very little Dairy -- I presume she would scorn my pleasures; I certainly do not envy hers -- -- We shall have a real thanksgiving this winter; the fruits of the Earth were never more abundant -- -- Charles has got from 7 Bushels of potatoes -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- My dearest Robert I cannot endure the thought of living on ‘till Spring without seeing you -- and I hope I shall not -- I feel all the while, as if something would turn up to enable me to go -- -- What can be the cause of Coles’ dejection? I have a great deal of curiosity to see Margaret in her new condition -- How has she deported herself to you? -- -- I am in continual trepidation on Mr Watson’s account -- I have been hoping all the while he would go this evening! -- I wish my dear Robert you would be kind enough to ask Mrs Brush the price of the hat she bought for me, and pay her -- -- If Harry has any money to pay me I wish you would take it and let it go towards the liquidation of my debt to you -- If it is not too troublesome to you my dear Brother I will thank you to send me the amount of my debt to you? -- -- I expect to hear from you in the course of the week -- -- -- -- All our friends here always remember you -- Do present mes amities to Monsieur Everard and his amiable family -- -- Good night My dearest Robert -- God bless you -- -- -- Ever YoursCMS -- I have opened my letter to say that Mr W starts tonight, and as it is very unpleasant this expresses a due anxiety to avoid risk --

Stockbridge June 3rd 1812 You see my dear Robert how promptly I am putting my threat in execution, & if you are troubled with very womanish loquacity this summer from my pen, you may consider it as retributive justice for your too free indulgence of your wits upon this subject -- -- I will not attempt to describe to you my dearest Brother the desolateness of the house since your departure, because I would not willingly communicate to you any degree of the pain I have felt Today I have hardly been without my chamber door & I have cheated the enemy of two or three hours by the aid of Doctor Young’s conjectures &c the same essay you was obliged to relinquish reading in consequence of your extreme debility, but who shall wonder if the greatest God of the Ancients nodded, that the giant mind of a modern Hero requires repose, & even his herculean frame bends beneath the potentiality of sleep -- -- The poor sofa is quite neglected since your departure, to me it looks like the ghost of my departed joys -- I can almost see with fancy’s eye the form of my dear Bob superincumbent upon it -- -- -- -- Papa went off to Lenox in very good spirits & from Charles' account has endured the fatigue of the Court surprisingly well -- I am a little afraid of the effect of this terrible northeast wind upon him -- By the way a fine precursor to the 4th of June -- Charles has spent the week with his favorite M’amselle Sprightly on the Lenox road, & says he finds it very delightful, and altogether convenient to call on the Gallery Belles (Std & Harris), during his morning and evening rides -- I think if they are not more like the Syrens in anything than their voices, they will not charm our Charley from his allegiance to his home -- -- I wish you was here at this moment -- What an inexplicable wish! I have a charming fire in my room and the world (the tumultuous world of Stockbridge) and all its plagues and vexations shut out, & locked out. And where are you my dear Brother? -- Well and happy I trust wherever you are -- To Him who will give peace to those whose ‘hearts are stayed on him, have I with my whole soul committed you that He may preserve and guide you is among my most fervent prayers -- May the God of Mercy, who has so eminently blessed us in this life finally bring us to that Inheritance purchased by the precious blood of his Son -- Doctor Jones has at length ascertained that poor little Sue’s collar bone is broken -- He thinks however that it will grow together again, without the painful operation of setting & leave no deformity but the little prominence you observed -- I am afraid he is deterred from doing it, by his unwillingness to inflict pain -- -- -- -- Mrs S has been uncommonly amiable and correct all the week -- -- -- I wish you would ask Frances to send me the pieces of Robert's bombaset clothes by the earliest opportunity -- I did expect a from her by the yesterday’s mail, I was disappointed -- remember me very affectionately to all both great & small at our own home, & suitably (as Aunt Anna D would say) to all my friends -- I watched last night, and have now written in the 4th of June. If I have given it a very stupid greeting you must forgive me -- -- I wish Frances would be kind enough to purchase me a pair of smooth dark kid gloves. I should prefer purple -- -- -- Good night my dearest Brother, Good night as if you were at my door -- Ever yours CMS

New York Nov'r 22'nd1808 We received your letter my dear Papa from Salem, yesterday Morning -- it is incomprehensible to us, that you should not have received any of Frances’s letters -- She has written three times, since you have been in Boston -- You say nothing of my poor representative, from which I presume you have received it. I confess its insignificance rendered it unworthy of an acknowledgement, but you know my dear Papa, there is a kind of parental pride in Authorship, which is perhaps too easily wounded and if I were ingenuously to tell you all, I should be compelled to confess that your addressing your letters exclusively to my elder Sister, has excited a little of that jealousy; which is a portion of my inheritance from the paternal estate I presume you will have heard long before this letter reaches Boston, of Theodore’s and Susan’s arrival in this City -- Susan is already almost recovered, by the most simple remedy in the world, the presence of her grand restorative, who may well boast with in relation to her, to be as universal a cure, as the most wonder working patent Medicine -- They are to be joined in holy wedlock on monday evening next, at Brockholst Livingston’s, in as private a manner, as propriety will admit of -- Her Aunts, and one or two very dear friends, Mr Watson, our dear Charles provided he arrives in season, Frances and myself are to compose the nuptial train -- Theodore has obtained a triumph similar to yours, and won a promise from poor Susan, that she will sacrifice her liberty of conscience, and be married in a most anti-dogmified,, plebian style, by a Presbyterian Clergyman, -- They will leave New York on the Wedn’y following, in Captain Bunker’s packet and will probably arrive at our dear home a fortnight before you -- -- You seem to have had some uneasiness excited by the secrecy of a late letter, written to me. You will I am sure be gratified to hear, that it was a motive of generosity towards me, that induced the kind writer of it, the refuse you the perusal of it -- I empower you my dear Papa to request her to show you the last letter I wrote her on the subject, if it is still in being that, together with a few words of explanation, or confession, (whichever you please to term it) will acquaint you with an affair about which, I should never have had any reserve towards you, had I not feared that it would have diminished that confidence, which you have so bountifully reposed in me -- -- -- -- -- Last Spring while I was in Boston, Miss Russell told she thought MrsJ unfriendly to her, she it from several sources, mentioning Mrs Derby, , Jay and I beleive James Savage. I was indignant at MrsJ’s continued & unparalleled abuse of a friend, who I thought so underserving of it -- I confirmed her suspicions, and moreover specified some of the Articles of defamation, though it was but "a sand on the sea shore” compared to the whole number -- I know not what motives you will ascribe to this conduct -- Perhaps you will think it was the common, tale-bearing, tattling propensity of a silly girl -- Permit me to say my dear Father I was not motivated by a feeling so dishonorable to me -- On a calm review of it, I have censured myself for it because I was indebted to Mrs -- for much kindness and because the communication, could subserve no good end but never shall I think the impulse that led me to it execrable -- Do my dear Papa, relieve me, by your opinion on the subject, and let it be as lenient as possible -- -- The family all unite with me in the kindest remembrance to you, and yours -- With the most ardent prayers for your health and happiness beleive me Your affy Catharine M Sedgwick

text: Boston Jan'y 5th 1813 A thousand thanks to you my dear Sister for devoting so much time to us, amidst your various cares, and perplexities -- To my dear Brother,too I am very much indebted for his most excellent and christian letter -- I have not been able to write you as I have wished -- various occupations and frequent interruptions, have distracted my attention -- At all times it has been a sourcesubject of gratitude that I had such a brother, and such a Sister, and that the christian bond that unites us, should annihilate the distance that separates us -- -- God grant that I may improve the dispensations of his Providence as you have done, that his chastening and his mercies may increase my love and devotion -- My dear Sister, our fears have been calmed by the favorable appearance that our Father’sdisorder put on, but for a few days past he has not gained, and, for two days I think he has lost ground -- -- -- He has been uniformly silent as to the his own feelings, and apprehensions till yesterday -- Yesterday Mrs S walked out for the first time -- and while she was gone I was alone with him -- -- He began said to me (without my introducing the subject) that he had for many years been extremely desirous to make a public profession of religion, (here he was so much agitated as to be obliged to stop for some time) He had been deterred from very unworthy motives that he had feard giving pain to Doctor West and many good people in Stockbridge by joining any other than their Church, and he couldnot bringing his feelings to joining that. He was so much overcome, that I made every effort to sustain and assure him -- I told him that Mr Channing had been desirous to see him He said that if he understood Mr Channing’s belief, it agreed with his better than any other Clergyman’s in Boston, and should it please God to restore to him sufficient health, it should be his first act to devote himself to him -- -- I suggested that should he wish it, Mr C would administer the sacrament to him here -- “ Not at present my love said he, for if it should please God I wish to do it in the face of the world” -- My dear Frances, I know you will be overwhelmed with gratitude, that we have so much to console us in any event -- How shall we evince our sense of the tender mercies of our God, and above all this last surpassing kindness -- -- This is but another instance of the importance of embracing the first opportunity of joining ourselves to the visible Church assure my dear Brother, that so deeply am I impressed with it, that no difficulties, no sacrifices of feeling will deter me from making every effort to possess such privileges, as I am indeed unworthy of -- Our dear Brothers are all kind and attentive, and our Father is now in some measure reaping the reward of his unexampled parental tenderness -- -- -- Robert cannot decide at present when he shall return -- -- Papa says “do my dear give my love to your Sister and Eben” -- -- I left the half handkerchief at home in Eliza’s care and desired her to send it to you or get it worked there, as you preferred -- -- Do you mean to have a lace or muslin vandyke? -- -- I am anxious to hear from your poor Children, and am afraid you will be exhausted with fatigue and anxiety _____ Continue to write my dearest Sister when you can, for your letters edify and delight me -- Mrs S and the boys join in love to you all -- May God have you in his holy keeping -- Ever yours aff'y C M S

text: Stockbridge June 3rd 1812 You see my dear Robert how promptly I am putting my threat in execution, & if you are troubled with very womanish loquacity this summer from my pen, you may consider it as retributive justice for your too free indulgence of your wits upon this subject -- -- I will not attempt to describe to you my dearest Brother the desolateness of the house since your departure, because I would not willingly communicate to you any degree of the pain I have felt Today I have hardly been without my chamber door & I have cheated the enemy of two or three hours by the aid of Doctor Young’s conjectures &c the same essay you was obliged to relinquish reading in consequence of your extreme debility, but who shall wonder if the greatest God of the Ancients nodded, that the giant mind of a modern Hero requires repose, & even his herculean frame bends beneath the potentiality of sleep -- -- The poor sofa is quite neglected since your departure, to me it looks like the ghost of my departed joys -- I can almost see with fancy’s eye the form of my dear Bob superincumbent upon it -- -- -- -- Papa went off to Lenox in very good spirits & from Charles's account has endured the fatigue of the Court surprisingly well -- I am a little afraid of the effect of this terrible north-east wind upon him -- By the way a fine precursor to the 4th of June -- Charles has spent the week with his favorite M’amselle Sprightly on the Lenox road, & says he finds it very delightful, and altogether convenient to call on the Gallery Belles (Std & Harris), during his morning and evening rides -- I think if they are not more like the Syrens in anything than their voices, they will not charm our stoical Charley from his allegiance to his home -- -- I wish you was here at this moment -- What an inexplicable wish! I have a charming fire in my room and the world (the tumultuous world of Stockbridge) and all its plagues and vexations shut out, & locked out. And where are you my dear Brother? -- Well and happy I trust wherever you are -- To Him who will give peace to those whose ‘hearts are stayed on him , have I with my whole soul committed you that He may preserve and guide you is among my most fervent prayers -- May the God of Mercy, who has so eminently blessed us in this life finally bring us to that Inheritance purchased by the precious blood of his Son -- Doctor Jones has at length ascertained that poor little Sue’s collar bone is broken -- He thinks however that it will grow together again, without the painful operation of setting & leave no deformity but the little prominence you observed -- I am afraid he is deterred from doing it, by his unwillingness to inflict pain -- -- -- -- Mrs S has been uncommonly amiable and correct all the week -- -- -- I wish you would ask Frances to send me the pieces of Robert's bombaset clothes by the earliest opportunity -- I did expect a from her by the yesterday’s mail, I was disappointed -- remember me very affectionately to all both great & small at our own home, & suitably (as Aunt Anna D would say) to all my friends -- I watched last night; and have now written in the 4th of June. If I have given it a very stupid greeting you must forgive me -- -- I wish Frances would be kind enough to purchase me a pair of smooth dark kid gloves. I should prefer purple -- -- -- Good night my dearest Brother, Good night as if you were at my door -- Ever yours CMS

Stockbridge Jan 24th 1800 My Dear Pappa You cannot conceive the pleasure I derived from the your excellent letter do not think My Dear Pappa that they are the less acceptable from being connected with Chales Indeed my Dear Pappa I do not get any body to give me a Copy for my Letters neither my good Brother Charles except the first letter he wrote you he the got Sister Frances to put in a few words for him our good Brothers are at home as they had a good opportunity to make us a short visit and return I meant to have written you A few lines of [Coarse?] hand and sent you this week but have not had it in my power as I have been so unwell as not to attend school with an ague in my face caused by an defective tooth which Dc Jones thought it would give me a great deal of pain as it was very sore I have parted with two since you left us Uncle & Aunt Sergeant have come from TuscaroraMama is better than when I wrote you last we heard from Sister Eliza Yesterday she was very well but her Children was not the family all send love except this scrawell My Dear Papa from your ever Dutiful Daughter Catharine Maria SedgwickTheodore Sedgwick
